verses.textLa: bovem de armento, et arietem, et agnum anniculum in holocaustum:

verses.textEn: and a he-goat for sin;
verses.textLa: hircumque pro peccato:

verses.textEn: and for victims of peace offerings: two oxen, five rams, five he-goats, and five one-year-old lambs. This was the oblation of Gamaliel, the son of Pedahzur.
verses.textLa: et in hostias pacificorum boves duos, arietes quinque, hircos quinque, agnos anniculos quinque. Hæc fuit oblatio Gamaliel filii Phadassur.

verses.textEn: On the ninth day, the leader of the sons of Benjamin, Abidan the son of Gideoni,
verses.textLa: Die nono princeps filiorum Beniamin, Abidan filius Gedeonis,

verses.textEn: offered a silver dish weighing one hundred thirty shekels, a silver bowl having seventy shekels, by the weight of the Sanctuary, and both were filled with fine wheat flour sprinkled with oil as a sacrifice,
verses.textLa: obtulit acetabulum argenteum appendens centum triginta siclos, phialam argenteam habentem septuaginta siclos ad pondus Sanctuarii, utrumque plenum simila conspersa oleo in sacrificum:

verses.textEn: a little mortar of gold weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,
verses.textLa: et mortariolum aureum appendens decem siclos plenum incenso:

verses.textEn: an ox from the herd, and a ram, and a one-year-old lamb as a holocaust,
verses.textLa: bovem de armento, et arietem, et agnum anniculum in holocaustum:

verses.textEn: and a he-goat for sin;
verses.textLa: hircumque pro peccato:

verses.textEn: and for victims of peace offerings: two oxen, five rams, five he-goats, and five one-year-old lambs. This was the oblation of Abidan, the son of Gideoni.
verses.textLa: et in hostias pacificorum boves duos, arietes quinque, hircos quinque, agnos anniculos quinque. Hæc fuit oblatio Abidan filii Gedeonis.

verses.textEn: On the tenth day, the leaders of the sons of Dan, Ahiezer the son of Ammishaddai,
verses.textLa: Die decimo princeps filiorum Dan, Ahiezer filius Ammisaddai

verses.textEn: offered a silver dish weighing one hundred thirty shekels, a silver bowl having seventy shekels, by the weight of the Sanctuary, and both were filled with fine wheat flour sprinkled with oil as a sacrifice,
verses.textLa: obtulit acetabulum argenteum appendens centum triginta siclos, phialam argenteam habentem septuaginta siclos, ad pondus Sanctuarii, utrumque plenum simila conspersa oleo in sacrificum:

verses.textEn: a little mortar of gold weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,
verses.textLa: mortariolum aureum appendens decem siclos plenum incenso:

verses.textEn: an ox from the herd, and a ram, and a one-year-old lamb as a holocaust,
verses.textLa: bovem de armento, et arietem, et agnum anniculum in holocaustum:

verses.textEn: and a he-goat for sin;
verses.textLa: hircumque pro peccato:

verses.textEn: and for victims of peace offerings: two oxen, five rams, five he-goats, and five one-year-old lambs. This was the oblation of Ahiezer, the son of Ammishaddai.
verses.textLa: et in hostias pacificorum boves duos, arietes quinque, hircos quinque, agnos anniculos quinque. Hæc fuit oblatio Ahiezer filii Ammisaddai.

verses.textEn: On the eleventh day, the leader of the sons of Asher, Pagiel the son of Ochran,
verses.textLa: Die undecimo princeps filiorum Aser, Phegiel filius Ochran

verses.textEn: offered a silver dish weighing one hundred thirty shekels, a silver bowl having seventy shekels, by the weight of the Sanctuary, and both were filled with fine wheat flour sprinkled with oil as a sacrifice,
verses.textLa: obtulit acetabulum argenteum appendens centum triginta siclos, phialam argenteam habentem septuaginta siclos ad pondus Sanctuarii, utrumque plenum simila conspersa oleo in sacrificum:

verses.textEn: a little mortar of gold weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,
verses.textLa: mortariolum aureum appendens decem siclos plenum incenso:

verses.textEn: an ox from the herd, and a ram, and a one-year-old lamb as a holocaust,
verses.textLa: bovem de armento, et arietem, et agnum anniculum in holocaustum:

verses.textEn: and a he-goat for sin;
verses.textLa: hircumque pro peccato:

verses.textEn: and for victims of peace offerings: two oxen, five rams, five he-goats, and five one-year-old lambs. This was the oblation of Pagiel, the son of Ochran.
verses.textLa: et in hostias pacificorum boves duos, arietes quinque, hircos quinque, agnos anniculos quinque. Hæc fuit oblatio Phegiel filii Ochran.

verses.textEn: On the twelfth day, the leader of the sons of Naphtali, Ahira the son of Enan,
verses.textLa: Die duodecimo princeps filiorum Nephthali, Ahira filius Enan

verses.textEn: offered a silver dish weighing one hundred thirty shekels, a silver bowl having seventy shekels, by the weight of the Sanctuary, and both were filled with fine wheat flour sprinkled with oil as a sacrifice,
verses.textLa: obtulit acetabulum argenteum appendens centum triginta siclos, phialam argenteam habentem septuaginta siclos ad pondus Sanctuarii, utrumque plenum simila oleo conspersa in sacrificum:

verses.textEn: a little mortar of gold weighing ten shekels, filled with incense,
verses.textLa: mortariolum aureum appendens decem siclos, plenum incenso:

verses.textEn: an ox from the herd, and a ram, and a one-year-old lamb as a holocaust,
verses.textLa: bovem de armento, et arietem, et agnum anniculum in holocaustum:

verses.textEn: and a he-goat for sin;
verses.textLa: hircumque pro peccato:

verses.textEn: and for victims of peace offerings: two oxen, five rams, five he-goats, and five one-year-old lambs. This was the oblation of Ahira, the son of Enan.
verses.textLa: et in hostias pacificorum boves duos, arietes quinque, hircos quinque, agnos anniculos quinque. Hæc fuit oblatio Ahira filii Enan.

verses.textEn: These were the oblations from the leaders of Israel for the dedication of the altar on the day when it was consecrated: twelve dishes of silver, twelve bowls of silver, twelve little mortars of gold,
verses.textLa: Hæc in dedicatione altaris oblata sunt a principibus Israel, in die qua consecratum est: acetabula argentea duodecim: phialæ argenteæ duodecim: mortariola aurea duodecim:

verses.textEn: such that each dish had one hundred thirty shekels of silver, and each bowl had seventy shekels, that is, putting all of the vessels from silver together, two thousand four hundred shekels, by the weight of the Sanctuary,
verses.textLa: ita ut centum triginta siclos argenti haberet unum acetabulum, et septuaginta siclos haberet una phiala: id est, in commune vasorum omnium ex argento sicli duo millia quadringenti, pondere Sanctuarii:

verses.textEn: and twelve little mortars of gold, filled with incense, weighing ten shekels by the weight of the Sanctuary, that is, all together one hundred twenty shekels of gold,
verses.textLa: mortariola aurea duodecim plena incenso denos siclos appendentia pondere Sanctuarii: id est, simul auri sicli centum viginti:

verses.textEn: and twelve oxen from the herd as a holocaust, twelve rams, twelve one-year-old lambs, with their libations, and twelve he-goats for sin;
verses.textLa: boves de armento in holocaustum duodecim, arietes duodecim, agni anniculi duodecim, et libamenta eorum: hirci duodecim pro peccato.

verses.textEn: and for victims of peace offerings: twenty-four oxen, sixty rams, sixty he-goats, and sixty one-year-old lambs. These were the oblations for the dedication of the altar, when it was anointed.
verses.textLa: In hostias pacificorum, boves viginti quattuor, arietes sexaginta, hirci sexaginta, agni anniculi sexaginta. Hæc oblata sunt in dedicatione altaris, quando unctum est.

verses.textEn: And when Moses entered into the tabernacle of the covenant, to consult the oracle, he heard the voice of One speaking to him from the propitiatory, which is over the ark of the testimony between the two cherubim, and there he also spoke to him.
verses.textLa: Cumque ingrederetur Moyses tabernaculum fœderis, ut consuleret oraculum, audiebat vocem loquentis ad se de propitiatorio quod erat super arcam testimonii inter duos Cherubim, unde et loquebatur ei.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Speak to Aaron, and you shall say to him: When you place the seven lamps, let the lampstand be set up on the south side. Therefore, give this instruction: that the lamps should look out from the region opposite the north, toward the table of the bread of the presence; they shall give light opposite that area, toward the area that the lampstand faces.”
verses.textLa: Loquere Aaron, et dices ad eum: Cum posueris septem lucernas, candelabrum in australi parte erigatur. Hoc igitur præcipe ut lucernæ contra boream e regione respiciant ad mensam panum propositionis, contra eam partem, quam candelabrum respicit, lucere debebunt.

verses.textEn: And Aaron did so, and he placed the lamps on the lampstand, just as the Lord had instructed Moses.
verses.textLa: Fecitque Aaron, et imposuit lucernas super candelabrum, ut præceperat Dominus Moysi.

verses.textEn: Now this was the workmanship of the lampstand: it was of ductile gold, both the main shaft and all that originated from both sides of the branches. According to the example that the Lord revealed to Moses, so did he make the lampstand.
verses.textLa: Hæc autem erat factura candelabri, ex auro ductili, tam medius stipes, quam cuncta quæ ex utroque calamorum latere nascebantur: iuxta exemplum quod ostendit Dominus Moysi, ita operatus est candelabrum.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Et locutus est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Take the Levites from the midst of the sons of Israel, and you shall purify them
verses.textLa: Tolle Levitas de medio filiorum Israel, et purificabis eos

verses.textEn: according to this ritual: Let them be sprinkled with the water of illumination, and let them shave off all the hairs of their body. And when they have washed their garments and have been cleansed,
verses.textLa: iuxta hunc ritum: Aspergantur aqua lustrationis, et radant omnes pilos carnis suæ. Cumque laverint vestimenta sua, et mundati fuerint,

verses.textEn: they shall take an ox from the herd, with its libation of fine wheat flour sprinkled with oil; then you shall receive another ox from the herd for sin.
verses.textLa: tollent bovem de armentis, et libamentum eius similam oleo conspersam: bovem autem alterum de armento tu accipies pro peccato:

verses.textEn: And you shall bring forward the Levites before the tabernacle of the covenant, calling together all the multitude of the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: et applicabis Levitas coram tabernaculo fœderis, convocata omni multitudine filiorum Israel.

verses.textEn: And when the Levites are before the Lord, the sons of Israel shall place their hands upon them.
verses.textLa: Cumque Levitæ fuerint coram Domino, ponent filii Israel manus suas super eos.

verses.textEn: And Aaron shall offer the Levites as a gift in the sight of the Lord, from the sons of Israel, so that they may serve in his ministry.
verses.textLa: Et offeret Aaron Levitas, munus in conspectu Domini a filiis Israel, ut serviant in ministerio eius.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the Levites shall place their hands upon the heads of the oxen; you shall make use of one of these for sin, and the other as a holocaust to the Lord, so that you may intercede for them.
verses.textLa: Levitæ quoque ponent manus suas super capita boum, e quibus unum facies pro peccato, et alterum in holocaustum Domini, ut depreceris pro eis.

verses.textEn: And you shall set the Levites in the sight of Aaron and his sons, and you shall consecrate those being offered to the Lord,
verses.textLa: Statuesque Levitas in conspectu Aaron et filiorum eius, et consecrabis oblatos Domino,

verses.textEn: and you shall separate them from the midst of the sons of Israel, so that they may be for me.
verses.textLa: ac separabis de medio filiorum Israel, ut sint mei.

verses.textEn: And after this, they shall enter the tabernacle of the covenant, in order to serve me. And so shall you purify and consecrate them as an oblation to the Lord. For they were given to me as a gift from the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Et postea ingredientur tabernaculum fœderis, ut serviant mihi. Sicque purificabis et consecrabis eos in oblationem Domini: quoniam dono donati sunt mihi a filiis Israel.

verses.textEn: I have accepted them in place of the firstborn which open every womb in Israel.
verses.textLa: Pro primogenitis quæ aperiunt omnem vulvam in Israel, accepi eos.

verses.textEn: For all the firstborn of the sons of Israel, as much from men as from beasts, are mine. From the day when I struck down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, I have sanctified them to myself.
verses.textLa: Mea sunt enim omnia primogenita filiorum Israel, tam ex hominibus quam ex iumentis. Ex die quo percussi omne primogenitum in Terra Ægypti, sanctificavi eos mihi:

verses.textEn: And I have taken the Levites in place of all the firstborn of the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: et tuli Levitas pro cunctis primogenitis filiorum Israel:

verses.textEn: And I have delivered them as a gift to Aaron and his sons, from the midst of the people, in order to serve me, for Israel, in the tabernacle of the covenant, and in order to pray for them, lest there be a scourge among the people, if they were to dare to approach to my Sanctuary.”
verses.textLa: tradidique eos dono Aaron et filiis eius de medio populi, ut serviant mihi pro Israel in tabernaculo fœderis, et orent pro eis ne sit in populo plaga, si ausi fuerint accedere ad Sanctuarium.

verses.textEn: And Moses and Aaron, and all the multitude of the sons of Israel, accomplished all that the Lord had commanded Moses concerning the Levites.
verses.textLa: Feceruntque Moyses et Aaron et omnis multitudo filiorum Israel super Levitas quæ præceperat Dominus Moysi:

verses.textEn: And they were purified, and they washed their garments. And Aaron lifted them up in the sight of the Lord, and he prayed for them,
verses.textLa: purificatique sunt, et laverunt vestimenta sua. Elevavitque eos Aaron in conspectu Domini, et oravit pro eis,

verses.textEn: so that, having been purified, they might enter to their duties in the tabernacle of the covenant before Aaron and his sons. Just as the Lord had instructed Moses about the Levites, so was it done.
verses.textLa: ut purificati ingrederentur ad officia sua in tabernaculum fœderis coram Aaron et filiis eius. Sicut præceperat Dominus Moysi de Levitis, ita factum est.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “This is the law of the Levites: From twenty-five years and above, they shall enter to minister in the tabernacle of the covenant.
verses.textLa: Hæc est lex Levitarum, A viginti quinque annis et supra, ingredientur ut ministrent in tabernaculo fœderis.

verses.textEn: And when they will have completed the fiftieth year of age, they shall cease to serve.
verses.textLa: Cumque quinquagesimum annum ætatis impleverint, servire cessabunt:

verses.textEn: And they shall be the ministers of their brothers in the tabernacle of the covenant, in order to care for the things that have been commended to them, but not to perform the works themselves. So shall you assign the Levites in their duties.”
verses.textLa: eruntque ministri fratrum suorum in tabernaculo fœderis, ut custodiant quæ sibi fuerunt commendata, opera autem ipsa non faciant. Sic dispones Levitis in custodiis suis.
verses.notes: This distinction between the roles of Levites and those of Aaron and his sons, the priests, is a similar distinction between the religious and the ordained. God cautions the people of Israel, and their leaders, not to permit Levites to act as if they were priests, lest a great tribulation come upon the people. Similarly, today, some religious and some lay persons are taking roles only fitting for the ordained. So this is a sign that the tribulation is near.

verses.textEn: The Lord spoke to Moses in the desert of Sinai, in the second year after they departed from the land of Egypt, in the first month, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutus est Dominus ad Moysen in deserto Sinai anno secundo, postquam egressi sunt de Terra Ægypti, mense primo dicens:

verses.textEn: “Let the sons of Israel observe the Passover at its proper time,
verses.textLa: Faciant filii Israel Phase in tempore suo,

verses.textEn: on the fourteenth day of this month, in the evening, according to all of its ceremonies and justifications.”
verses.textLa: quartadecima die mensis huius ad vesperam, iuxta omnes ceremonias et iustificationes eius.

verses.textEn: And Moses instructed the sons of Israel, so that they would observe the Passover.
verses.textLa: Præcepitque Moyses filiis Israel ut facerent Phase.

verses.textEn: And they observed it at its proper time: on the fourteenth day of the month, in the evening, at mount Sinai. The sons of Israel acted according to all the things that the Lord had commanded Moses.
verses.textLa: Qui fecerunt tempore suo: quartadecima die mensis ad vesperam in monte Sinai. Iuxta omnia quæ mandaverat Dominus Moysi, fecerunt filii Israel.

verses.textEn: But behold, certain ones, who were not able to observe the Passover on that day, being unclean because of the life of a man, approaching Moses and Aaron,
verses.textLa: Ecce autem quidam immundi super anima hominis, qui non poterant facere Phase in die illo, accedentes ad Moysen et Aaron,

verses.textEn: said to them: “We are unclean because of the life of a man. Why have we been cheated, in that we are not permitted to offer, at its proper time, the oblation to the Lord among the sons of Israel?”
verses.textLa: dixerunt eis: Immundi sumus super anima hominis. Quare fraudamur ut non valeamus oblationem offerre Domino in tempore suo inter filios Israel?

verses.textEn: And Moses responded to them: “Remain, so that I may consult the Lord, as to what he will rule about you.”
verses.textLa: Quibus respondit Moyses: State ut consulam quid præcipiat Dominus de vobis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Say to the sons of Israel: The man who becomes unclean because of a life, or if he is on a distant journey within your nation, let him observe the Passover to the Lord.
verses.textLa: Loquere filiis Israel: Homo qui fuerit immundus super anima, sive in via procul in gente vestra, faciat Phase Domino

verses.textEn: In the second month, on the fourteenth day of the month, in the evening, they shall eat it with unleavened bread and wild lettuce.
verses.textLa: in mense secundo, quartadecima die mensis ad vesperam: cum azymis et lactucis agrestibus comedent illud:

verses.textEn: They shall not leave behind any of it until morning, and they shall not break a bone of it; they shall observe all the rituals of the Passover.
verses.textLa: non relinquent ex eo quippiam usque mane, et os eius non confringent, omnem ritum Phase observabunt.

verses.textEn: But if any man was both clean, and not on a journey, and yet he did not observe the Passover, that soul shall be exterminated from among his people, because he did not offer the sacrifice to the Lord in its time. He shall bear his sin.
verses.textLa: Si quis autem et mundus est, et in itinere non fuit, et tamen non fecit Phase, exterminabitur anima illa de populis suis, quia sacrificium Domino non obtulit tempore suo: peccatum suum ipse portabit.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the sojourner and the newcomer, if they are among you, shall observe the Passover to the Lord according to its ceremonies and justifications. The same precept shall be with you, as much for the newcomer as for the native.”
verses.textLa: Peregrinus quoque et advena si fuerint apud vos, facient Phase Domino iuxta ceremonias et iustificationes eius. Præceptum idem erit apud vos tam advenæ quam indigenæ.

verses.textEn: And so, on the day when the tabernacle was raised, a cloud covered it. But over the tabernacle, from evening until morning, there was, as it seemed, the appearance of fire.
verses.textLa: Igitur die qua erectum est tabernaculum, operuit illud nubes. A vespere autem super tentorium erat quasi species ignis usque mane.

verses.textEn: This was so continually: throughout the day a cloud covered it, and throughout the night, the appearance of fire.
verses.textLa: Sic fiebat iugiter: per diem operiebat illud nubes, et per noctem quasi species ignis.

verses.textEn: And when the cloud that was protecting the tabernacle had been taken up, then the sons of Israel advanced forward, and in the place where the cloud had remained standing, there they made camp.
verses.textLa: Cumque ablata fuisset nubes, quæ tabernaculum protegebat, tunc proficiscebantur filii Israel: et in loco ubi stetisset nubes, ibi castrametabantur.

verses.textEn: Upon the order of the Lord they advanced, and upon his order they fixed the tabernacle. All the days during which the cloud was standing over the tabernacle, they remained in the same place.
verses.textLa: Ad imperium Domini proficiscebantur, et ad imperium illius figebant tabernaculum. Cunctis diebus quibus stabat nubes super tabernaculum, manebant in eodem loco:

verses.textEn: And if it happened that it remained for a long time over it, the sons of Israel kept the night watches of the Lord, and they did not advance,
verses.textLa: et si evenisset ut multo tempore maneret super illud, erant filii Israel in excubiis Domini, et non proficiscebantur
verses.notes: The word ‘excubiis’ literally means to recline outside; in this context, it refers to keeping the four watches of the night.

verses.textEn: during as many days as the cloud remained over the tabernacle. At the command of the Lord they raised their tents, and at his command they took them down.
verses.textLa: quot diebus fuisset nubes super tabernaculum. Ad imperium Domini erigebant tentoria, et ad imperium illius deponebant.

verses.textEn: If the cloud remained from evening until morning, and immediately, at first light, it left the tabernacle, they set out. And if it withdrew after a day and a night, they dismantled their tents.
verses.textLa: Si fuisset nubes a vespere usque mane, et statim diluculo tabernaculum reliquisset, proficiscebantur: et, si post diem et noctem recessisset, dissipabant tentoria.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, whether it remained over the tabernacle for two days, or one month, or a longer time, the sons of Israel remained in the same place, and they did not set out. Then, as soon as it withdrew, they moved the camp.
verses.textLa: Si vero biduo aut uno mense vel longiori tempore fuisset super tabernaculum, manebant filii Israel in eodem loco, et non proficiscebantur: statim autem ut recessisset, movebant castra.

verses.textEn: By the word of the Lord they fixed their tents, and by his word they advanced. And they kept the night watches of the Lord, according to his command by the hand of Moses.
verses.textLa: Per verbum Domini figebant tentoria, et per verbum illius proficiscebantur: erantque in excubiis Domini iuxta imperium eius per manum Moysi.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Make for yourself two trumpets of ductile silver, with which you may be able to call together the multitude when the camp is to be moved.
verses.textLa: Fac tibi duas tubas argenteas ductiles, quibus convocare possis multitudinem quando movenda sunt castra.

verses.textEn: And when you sound the trumpets, all the multitude shall gather to you at the door of the tabernacle of the covenant.
verses.textLa: Cumque increpueris tubis, congregabitur ad te omnis turba ad ostium tabernaculi fœderis.

verses.textEn: If you sound it only once, the leaders and the heads of the multitude of Israel shall come to you.
verses.textLa: Si semel clangueris, venient ad te principes, et capita multitudinis Israel.

verses.textEn: But if the sound of the trumpets is prolonged, but with interruptions, those who are toward the east side shall move the camp first.
verses.textLa: Si autem prolixior atque concisus clangor increpuerit, movebunt castra primi qui sunt ad orientalem plagam.

verses.textEn: Then, at the second sounding of the trumpet with the same cadence, those who live toward the south shall take up their tents. And the remainder shall act in like manner, when the trumpets shall reverberate for a departure.
verses.textLa: In secundo autem sonitu et pari ululatu tubæ, levabunt tentoria qui habitant ad meridiem. Et iuxta hunc modum reliqui facient, ululantibus tubis in profectionem.

verses.textEn: But when the people are to be gathered together, the sound of the trumpets shall be simple, and the sounds shall not be separated.
verses.textLa: Quando autem congregandus est populus, simplex tubarum clangor erit, et non concise ululabunt.

verses.textEn: Now it is the sons of Aaron the priest who shall sound the trumpets. And this shall be an everlasting ordinance, in your generations.
verses.textLa: Filii autem Aaron sacerdotes clangent tubis: eritque hoc legitimum sempiternum in generationibus vestris.

verses.textEn: If you go forth to war from your land, against the enemies who set out against you, you shall sound the trumpets repeatedly, and there shall be a remembrance of you before the Lord your God, so that you may be rescued from the hands of your enemies.
verses.textLa: Si exieritis ad bellum de terra vestra contra hostes qui dimicant adversum vos, clangetis ululantibus tubis, et erit recordatio vestri coram Domino Deo vestro, ut eruamini de manibus inimicorum vestrorum.
verses.notes: The word ‘ululantibus’ refers to a sound that is rolling, or undulating, or repetitive in some way. The combination of ‘clangetis ululantibus’ indicates that the trumpets are to be sounded repeatedly.

verses.textEn: If at any time you will have a banquet, and on feast days, and on the first days of the months, you shall sound the trumpets over the holocausts and the peace-offering victims, so that they may be for you as a remembrance by your God. I am the Lord your God.”
verses.textLa: Si quando habebitis epulum, et dies festos, et calendas, canetis tubis super holocaustis, et pacificis victimis, ut sint vobis in recordationem Dei vestri. Ego Dominus Deus vester.

verses.textEn: In the second year, in the second month, on the twentieth day of the month, the cloud was lifted up from the tabernacle of the covenant.
verses.textLa: Anno secundo, mense secundo, vigesima die mensis elevata est nubes de tabernaculo fœderis:

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel set out by their companies from the desert of Sinai, and the cloud rested in the wilderness of Paran.
verses.textLa: profectique sunt filii Israel per turmas suas de deserto Sinai, et recubuit nubes in solitudine Pharan.

verses.textEn: And the first to move their camp, according to the command of the Lord by the hand of Moses,
verses.textLa: Moveruntque castra primi iuxta imperium Domini in manu Moysi.

verses.textEn: were the sons of Judah by their companies, whose leader was Nahshon the son of Amminadab.
verses.textLa: Filii Iuda per turmas suas: quorum princeps erat Nahasson filius Aminadab.

verses.textEn: In the tribe of the sons of Issachar, the leader was Nathanael the son of Zuar.
verses.textLa: In tribu filiorum Issachar fuit princeps Nathanael filius Suar.

verses.textEn: In the tribe of Zebulon, the leader was Eliab the son of Helon.
verses.textLa: In tribu Zabulon erat princeps Eliab filius Helon.

verses.textEn: And the tabernacle was taken down, because the sons of Gershon and Merari, who carry it, were departing.
verses.textLa: Depositumque est tabernaculum, quod portantes egressi sunt filii Gerson et Merari.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Ruben also set out, by their companies and ranks, whose leader was Elizur the son of Shedeur.
verses.textLa: Profectique sunt et filii Ruben, per turmas et ordinem suum: quorum princeps erat Helisur filius Sedeur.

verses.textEn: And in the tribe of Simeon, the leader was Shelumiel the son of Zurishaddai.
verses.textLa: In tribu autem filiorum Simeon, princeps fuit Salamiel filius Surisaddai.

verses.textEn: And in the tribe of Gad, the leader was Eliasaph the son of Reuel.
verses.textLa: Porro in tribu Gad erat princeps Eliasaph filius Duel.

verses.textEn: Then the Kohathites also set out, carrying the Sanctuary. The tabernacle was carried, all the while, until they arrived at the place for setting it up.
verses.textLa: Profectique sunt et Caathitæ portantes Sanctuarium. Tamdiu tabernaculum portabatur, donec venirent ad erectionis locum.

verses.textEn: The sons of Ephraim also moved their camp by their companies, and the leader of their army was Elishama the son of Ammihud.
verses.textLa: Moverunt castra et filii Ephraim per turmas suas, in quorum exercitu princeps erat Elisama filius Ammiud.

verses.textEn: And in the tribe of the sons of Manasseh, the leader was Gamaliel the son of Pedahzur.
verses.textLa: In tribu autem filiorum Manasse princeps fuit Gamaliel filius Phadassur.

verses.textEn: And in the tribe of Benjamin, the leader was Abidan the son of Gideoni.
verses.textLa: Et in tribu Beniamin erat dux Abidan filius Gedeonis.

verses.textEn: The last of all the camp to set out were the sons of Dan by their companies, and the leader of their army was Ahiezer the son of Ammishaddai.
verses.textLa: Novissimi castrorum omnium profecti sunt filii Dan per turmas suas, in quorum exercitu princeps fuit Ahiezer filius Ammisaddai.

verses.textEn: And in the tribe of the sons of Asher, the leader was Pagiel the son of Ochran.
verses.textLa: In tribu autem filiorum Aser erat princeps Phegiel filius Ochran.

verses.textEn: And in the tribe of the sons of Naphtali, the leader was Ahira the son of Enan.
verses.textLa: Et in tribu filiorum Nephthali princeps fuit Ahira filius Enan.

verses.textEn: These were the camps and departures of the sons of Israel by their companies, when they went forth.
verses.textLa: Hæc sunt castra, et profectiones filiorum Israel per turmas suas quando egrediebantur.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to Hobab the son of Raguel the Midianite, his kinsman: “We are setting out to the place which the Lord will give to us. Come with us, so that we may do good to you. For the Lord has promised good things to Israel.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Moyses Hobab filio Raguel Madianitæ, cognato suo: Proficiscimur ad locum, quem Dominus daturus est nobis: veni nobiscum, ut benefaciamus tibi: quia Dominus bona promisit Israeli.

verses.textEn: And he answered him, “I will not go with you, but I will return to my own land, in which I was born.”
verses.textLa: Cui ille respondit: Non vadam tecum, sed revertar in terram meam, in qua natus sum.

verses.textEn: And he said: “Do not choose to leave us. For you know in which places in the desert we ought to make camp, and so you shall be our guide.
verses.textLa: Et ille: Noli, inquit, nos relinquere: tu enim nosti in quibus locis per desertum castra ponere debeamus, et eris ductor noster.

verses.textEn: And if you come with us, whatever will be best among the riches which the Lord will deliver to us, we will give to you.”
verses.textLa: Cumque nobiscum veneris, quidquid optimum fuerit ex opibus, quas nobis traditurus est Dominus, dabimus tibi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they set out from the Mountain of the Lord on a journey of three days. And the ark of the covenant of the Lord preceded them, for three days, in order to provide a place for the camp.
verses.textLa: Profecti sunt ergo de Monte Domini viam trium dierum, arcaque fœderis Domini præcedebat eos, per dies tres providens castrorum locum.

verses.textEn: Likewise, the cloud of the Lord was over them, throughout the day, while they proceeded.
verses.textLa: Nubes quoque Domini super eos erat per diem cum incederent.

verses.textEn: And when the ark was lifted up, Moses said, “Rise up, O Lord, and let your enemies be scattered, and let those who hate you flee from your face.”
verses.textLa: Cumque elevaretur arca, dicebat Moyses: Surge Domine, et dissipentur inimici tui, et fugiant qui oderunt te, a facie tua.

verses.textEn: And when it was set down, he said: “Return, O Lord, to the multitude of the army of Israel.”
verses.textLa: Cum autem deponeretur, aiebat: Revertere Domine, ad multitudinem exercitus Israel.

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, there arose a murmur among the people against the Lord, as if they were grief-stricken because of their labors. And when the Lord had heard it, he was angry. And when the fire of the Lord was enflamed against them, it devoured those who were at the extreme end of the camp.
verses.textLa: Interea ortum est murmur populi, quasi dolentium pro labore, contra Dominum. Quod cum audisset Dominus, iratus est. Et accensus in eos ignis Domini devoravit extremam castrorum partem.
verses.notes: The most faithful were those camped immediately around the Tabernacle. The common people who were mainly non-Hebrew, were at the outer edges of the camp. It is mainly these who were murmuring against the Lord.

verses.textEn: And when the people had cried out to Moses, Moses prayed to the Lord, and the fire was consumed.
verses.textLa: Cumque clamasset populus ad Moysen, oravit Moyses ad Dominum, et absorptus est ignis.

verses.textEn: And he called the name of that place, ‘The Burning,’ because the fire of the Lord had burned against them.
verses.textLa: Vocavitque nomen loci illius, Incensio: eo quod incesus fuisset contra eos ignis Domini.

verses.textEn: So then, the mix of common people, who had ascended with them, were enflamed with desire, and sitting and weeping, with the sons of Israel joining them, they said, “Who will give us flesh to eat?
verses.textLa: Vulgus quippe promiscuum, quod ascenderat cum eis, flagravit desiderio, sedens et flens, iunctis sibi pariter filiis Israel, et ait: Quis dabit nobis ad vescendum carnes?
verses.notes: When the Israelites departed from Egypt, many of the non-Hebrews were so impressed by the signs from God, that they departed with them.

verses.textEn: We remember the fish that we ate freely in Egypt; we call to mind the cucumbers, and melons, and leeks, and onions, and garlic.
verses.textLa: Recordamur piscium quos comedebamus in Ægypto gratis: in mentem nobis veniunt cucumeres, et pepones, porrique, et cepe, et allia.

verses.textEn: Our life is dry; our eyes look out to see nothing but manna.”
verses.textLa: Anima nostra arida est, nihil aliud respiciunt oculi nostri nisi Man.

verses.textEn: Now the manna was like coriander seed, but with the color of bdellium.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Man quasi semen coriandri, coloris bdellii.

verses.textEn: And the people wandered about, gathering it, and they crushed it with a millstone, or ground it with a mortar; then they boiled it in a pot, and made biscuits out of it, with a taste like bread made with oil.
verses.textLa: Circuibatque populus, et colligens illud, frangebat mola, sive terebat in mortario, coquens in olla, et faciens ex eo tortulas saporis quasi panis oleati.

verses.textEn: And when the dew descended in the night over the camp, the manna descended together with it.
verses.textLa: Cumque descederet nocte super castra ros, descendebat pariter et Man.

verses.textEn: And so, Moses heard the people weeping by their families, each one at the door of his tent. And the fury of the Lord was greatly enflamed. And to Moses also the matter seemed intolerable.
verses.textLa: Audivit ergo Moyses flentem populum per familias, singulos per ostia tentorii sui. Iratusque est furor Domini valde: sed et Moysi intoleranda res visa est.

verses.textEn: And so he said to the Lord: “Why have you afflicted your servant? Why do I not find favor before you? And why have you imposed the weight of this entire people upon me?
verses.textLa: Et ait ad Dominum: Cur afflixisti servum tuum? quare non invenio gratiam coram te? et cur imposuisti pondus universi populi huius super me?

verses.textEn: Could I have conceived this entire multitude, or have given birth to them, so that you might say to me: Carry them in your bosom, as a nursemaid usually carries a little infant, and bring them into the land, about which you have sworn to their fathers?
verses.textLa: Numquid ego concepi omnem hanc multitudinem, vel genui eam, ut dicas mihi: Porta eos in sinu tuo sicut portare solet nutrix infantulum, et defer in terram, pro qua iurasti patribus eorum?

verses.textEn: From where would I obtain the flesh to give to so great a multitude? They weep against me, saying, ‘Give us flesh, so that we may eat.’
verses.textLa: Unde mihi carnes ut dem tantæ multitudini? Flent contra me, dicentes: Da nobis carnes ut comedamus.

verses.textEn: I alone am unable to sustain this entire people, because it is too heavy for me.
verses.textLa: Non possum solus sustinere omnem hunc populum, quia gravis est mihi.

verses.textEn: But if it seems to you otherwise, I beg you to put me to death, and so may I find grace in your eyes, lest I be afflicted with such evils.”
verses.textLa: Sin aliter tibi videtur, obsecro ut interficias me, et inveniam gratiam in oculis tuis, ne tantis afficiar malis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses: “Gather to me seventy men from the elders of Israel, whom you know to be elders, as well as teachers, of the people. And you shall lead them to the door of the tabernacle of the covenant, and you shall cause them to stand there with you,
verses.textLa: Et dixit Dominus ad Moysen: Congrega mihi septuaginta viros de senibus Israel, quos tu nosti quod senes populi sint ac magistri: et duces eos ad ostium tabernaculi fœderis, faciesque ibi stare tecum,

verses.textEn: so that I may descend and speak to you. And I will take from your spirit, and I will deliver it to them, so that, with you, they may sustain the burden of the people, and so that you will not be weighed down alone.
verses.textLa: ut descendam et loquar tibi: et auferam de spiritu tuo, tradamque eis, ut sustentent tecum onus populi, et non tu solus graveris.

verses.textEn: You shall also say to the people: Be sanctified. Tomorrow you will eat flesh. For I have heard you say: ‘Who will give us flesh to eat? It was well with us in Egypt.’ So then, may the Lord give you flesh. And you will eat,
verses.textLa: Populo quoque dices: Sanctificamini: cras comedetis carnes. Ego enim audivi vos dicere: Quis dabit nobis escas carnium? Bene nobis erat in Ægypto. Ut det vobis Dominus carnes, et comedatis:

verses.textEn: not for one day, nor for two, nor for five, nor for ten, nor even for twenty,
verses.textLa: non uno die, nec duobus, vel quinque aut decem, nec viginti quidem,

verses.textEn: but for up to a month of days, until it exits from your nostrils, and until it turns into nausea for you, because you have slipped away from the Lord, who is in your midst, and because you have wept before him, saying: ‘Why did we go forth out of Egypt?’ ”
verses.textLa: sed usque ad mensem dierum, donec exeat per nares vestras, et vertatur in nauseam, eo quod replueritis Dominum, qui in medio vestri est, et fleveritis coram eo, dicentes: Quare egressi sumus ex Ægypto?

verses.textEn: And Moses said: “There are six hundred thousand footmen of this people, and yet you say, ‘I will give them flesh to eat for a whole month.’
verses.textLa: Et ait Moyses: Sexcenta millia peditum huius populi sunt, et tu dicis: Dabo eis esum carnium mense integro.

verses.textEn: Could a multitude of sheep and oxen be slain, so that there would be enough food? Or will the fishes of the sea be gathered together, in order to satisfy them?”
verses.textLa: Numquid ovium et boum multitudo cædetur, ut possit sufficere ad cibum? Vel omnes pisces maris in unum congregabuntur, ut eos satient?

verses.textEn: And the Lord answered him: “Can the hand of the Lord be ineffective? Soon now, you shall see whether my word will be fulfilled in this work.”
verses.textLa: Cui respondit Dominus: Numquid manus Domini invalida est? Iam nunc videbis utrum meus sermo opere compleatur.

verses.textEn: And so, Moses went and explained the words of the Lord to the people. Gathering together seventy men from the elders of Israel, he caused them to stand around the tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Venit igitur Moyses, et narravit populo verba Domini, congregans septuaginta viros de senibus Israel, quos stare fecit circa tabernaculum.

verses.textEn: And the Lord descended in a cloud, and he spoke to him, taking from the Spirit which was in Moses, and giving to the seventy men. And when the Spirit had rested in them, they prophesied; nor did they cease afterwards.
verses.textLa: Descenditque Dominus per nubem, et locutus est ad eum, auferens de Spiritu qui erat in Moyse, et dans septuaginta viris. Cumque requievisset in eis Spiritus, prophetaverunt, nec ultra cessaverunt.

verses.textEn: Now there had remained in the camp two of the men, of whom one was called Eldad, and the other Medad, upon whom the Spirit rested; for they also had been enrolled, but they did not go forth to the tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Remanserat autem in castris duo viri, quorum unus vocabatur Eldad, et alter Medad, super quos requievit Spiritus. Nam et ipsi descripti fuerant, et non exierant ad tabernaculum.

verses.textEn: And when they were prophesying in the camp, a boy ran and reported to Moses, saying: “Eldad and Medad prophesy in the camp.”
verses.textLa: Cumque prophetarent in castris, cucurrit puer, et nunciavit Moysi, dicens: Eldad et Medad prophetant in castris.

verses.textEn: Promptly, Joshua the son of Nun, the minister of Moses and chosen from many, said: “My lord Moses, prohibit them.”
verses.textLa: Statim Iosue filius Nun, minister Moysi, et electus e pluribus, ait: Domine mi Moyses prohibe eos.

verses.textEn: But he said, “Why are you jealous on my behalf? Who decides that any of the people may prophesy and that God may give to them his Spirit?”
verses.textLa: At ille: Quid, inquit, æmularis pro me? Quis tribuat ut omnis populus prophetet, et det eis Dominus Spiritum suum?

verses.textEn: And Moses returned, with those greater by birth of Israel, into the camp.
verses.textLa: Reversusque est Moyses, et maiores natu Israel in castra.

verses.textEn: Then a wind, going out from the Lord and moving forcefully across the sea, brought quails and cast them into the camp, across a distance of one day’s journey, in every part of the camp all around, and they flew in the air two cubits high above the ground.
verses.textLa: Ventus autem egrediens a Domino arreptans trans mare coturnices detulit, et demisit in castra itinere quantum uno die confici potest, ex omni parte castrorum per circuitum, volabantque in aere duobus cubitis altitudine super terram.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the people, rising up, gathered quails all that day and night, and the next day; he who did least well gathered ten homers. And they dried them throughout the camp.
verses.textLa: Surgens ergo populus toto die illo, et nocte, ac die altero, congregavit coturnicum, qui parum, decem coros: et siccaverunt eas per gyrum castrorum.

verses.textEn: The flesh was still between their teeth, neither had this kind of food ceased, and behold, the fury of the Lord was provoked against the people, and he struck them with an exceedingly great scourge.
verses.textLa: Adhuc carnes erant in dentibus eorum, nec defecerat huiuscemodi cibus: et ecce furor Domini concitatus in populum, percussit eum plaga magna nimis.

verses.textEn: And that place was called, ‘The Graves of Lust.’ For there, they buried the people who had desired. Then, departing from the Graves of Lust, they arrived in Hazeroth, and they stayed there.
verses.textLa: Vocatusque est ille locus, Sepulchra concupiscentiæ: ibi enim sepelierunt populum qui desideraverat. Egressi autem de Sepulchris concupiscentiæ, venerunt in Haseroth, et manserunt ibi.
verses.notes: Other translations incorrectly obscure this reference to the sexual sins of the people. Fasting is opposed to sexual sins. When the people, ate freely, no longer fasting on Manna (similar to bread) and water, they fell into sexual sins. The eating of quails was not sin, but through self-indulgence in what should not have been sinful, they fell into sin, and subsequently into even greater sins.

verses.textEn: And Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses, because of his wife, an Ethiopian,
verses.textLa: Locutaque est Maria et Aaron contra Moysen propter uxorem eius Æthiopissam,
verses.notes: Notice that Miriam’s name is listed first. This indicates that she was putting herself above Aaron as well as Moses, and it is a foreshadowing of those women who wish to put themselves above men by claiming to be ordained as Bishops and priests. Notice also that they first denigrate Moses by criticizing him unfairly. Then they try to life themselves up.

verses.textEn: and they said: “Has the Lord spoken only through Moses? Has he not also spoken similarly to us?” And when the Lord had heard this,
verses.textLa: et dixerunt: Num per solum Moysen locutus est Dominus? Nonne et nobis similiter est locutus? Quod cum audisset Dominus,
verses.notes: This event was a foreshadowing of the rebellion in the Church against proper Church authority, against the authority of the Pope over the Bishops, against the authority of the Pope and Bishops over priests, deacons, and religious, and against the teaching of the Church that women cannot be Pope, Cardinal, Bishop, or priest in the Church. Miriam speaks as if she were equal to Moses in his role over Israel, just as some women speak as if they could be ordained as priests or Bishops, or as if it could ever be God’s will for them to lead men. God rebukes Aaron and Miriam for disdaining the roles given to each of them by God and for desiring a role not given to them. Notice also that even Miriam and Aaron know that God speaks to them, but through Moses. Yet they ignore that difference.

verses.textEn: (for Moses was a man exceedingly meek, beyond all the men who were living upon the earth)
verses.textLa: (erat enim Moyses vir mitissimus super omnes homines qui morabantur in terra)

verses.textEn: immediately he spoke to him, and to Aaron and Miriam, “Go out, you three only, to the tabernacle of the covenant.” And when they had gone out,
verses.textLa: statim locutus est ad eum, et ad Aaron et Mariam: Egredimini vos tantum tres ad tabernaculum fœderis. Cumque fuissent egressi,

verses.textEn: the Lord descended in a column of cloud, and he stood at the entrance of the tabernacle, calling to Aaron and Miriam. And when they had advanced,
verses.textLa: descendit Dominus in columna nubis, et stetit in introitu tabernaculi vocans Aaron et Mariam. Qui cum issent,

verses.textEn: he said to them: “Listen to my words. If there will be among you a prophet of the Lord, I will appear to him in a vision, or I will speak to him through a dream.
verses.textLa: dixit ad eos: Audite sermones meos: si quis fuerit inter vos propheta Domini, in visione apparebo ei, vel per somnium loquar ad illum.

verses.textEn: But it is not so with my servant Moses, who is the most faithful in all my house.
verses.textLa: At non talis servus meus Moyses, qui in omni domo mea fidelissimus est:

verses.textEn: For I speak with him mouth to mouth, and plainly. And not through enigmas and figures does he perceive the Lord. Therefore, why were you not afraid to disparage my servant Moses?”
verses.textLa: ore enim ad os loquor ei: et palam, et non per ænigmata et figuras Dominum videt. Quare ergo non timuistis detrahere servo meo Mosyi?

verses.textEn: And being angry against them, he went away.
verses.textLa: Iratusque contra eos, abiit:

verses.textEn: Likewise, the cloud which was over the tabernacle withdrew. And behold, Miriam appeared to be white with a leprosy, like snow. And when Aaron had looked upon her, and he had seen the spreading of the leprosy,
verses.textLa: nubes quoque recessit quæ erat super tabernaculum: et ecce Maria apparuit candens lepra quasi nix. Cumque respexisset eam Aaron, et vidisset perfusam lepra,

verses.textEn: he said to Moses: “I beg you, my lord, not to impose upon us this sin, which we have committed foolishly.
verses.textLa: ait ad Moysen: Obsecro domine mi, ne imponas nobis hoc peccatum quod stulte commisimus,

verses.textEn: Do not let this one be like one who is dead, or like an abortion that has been cast from the womb of her mother. Behold, half of her flesh is already consumed by leprosy.”
verses.textLa: ne fiat hæc quasi mortua, et ut abortivum quod proiicitur de vulva matris suæ. Ecce iam medium carnis eius devoratum est a lepra.

verses.textEn: And Moses cried out to the Lord, saying, “O God, I beg you: heal her.”
verses.textLa: Clamavitque Moyses ad Dominum, dicens: Deus, obsecro, sana eam.

verses.textEn: And the Lord answered him: “If her father had spit on her face, should she not have been filled with shame for at least seven days? Let her be separated, outside the camp, for seven days, and after that, she will be called back.”
verses.textLa: Cui respondit Dominus: Si pater eius spuisset in faciem illius, nonne debuerat saltem septem diebus rubore suffundi? Separetur septem diebus extra castra, et postea revocabitur.

verses.textEn: And so Miriam was excluded from the camp for seven days. And the people did not move from that place, until Miriam was called back.
verses.textLa: Exclusa est itaque Maria extra castra septem diebus: et populus non est motus de loco illo, donec revocata est Maria.

verses.textEn: And the people set out from Hazeroth, and they pitched their tents in the desert of Paran.
verses.textLa: Profectusque est populus de Haseroth fixis tentoriis in deserto Pharan.

verses.textEn: And there, the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Ibique locutus est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Send men, who may examine the land of Canaan, which I will give to the sons of Israel, one from the rulers of each tribe.”
verses.textLa: Mitte viros, qui considerent Terram Chanaan, quam daturus sum filiis Israel, singulos de singulis tribubus, ex principibus.

verses.textEn: Moses did what the Lord had commanded, sending, from the desert of Paran, leading men, whose names are these:
verses.textLa: Fecit Moyses quod Dominus imperaverat, de deserto Pharan mittens principes viros, quorum ista sunt nomina.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Ruben, Shammua the son of Zaccur;
verses.textLa: De tribu Ruben, Sammua filium Zechur.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Simeon, Shaphat the son of Hori;
verses.textLa: De tribu Simeon, Saphat filium Huri.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Judah, Caleb the son of Jephunneh;
verses.textLa: De tribu Iuda, Caleb filium Iephone.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Issachar, Igal the son of Joseph;
verses.textLa: De tribu Issachar, Igal filium Ioseph.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Ephraim, Hosea the son of Nun;
verses.textLa: De tribu Ephraim, Osee filium Nun.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Benjamin, Palti the son of Raphu;
verses.textLa: De tribu Beniamin, Phalti filium Raphu.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Zebulon, Gaddiel the son of Sodi;
verses.textLa: De tribu Zabulon, Geddiel filium Sodi.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Joseph, of the scepter of Manasseh, Gaddi the son of Susi;
verses.textLa: De tribu Ioseph, sceptri Manasse, Gaddi filium Susi.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Dan, Ammiel the son of Gemalli;
verses.textLa: De tribu Dan, Ammiel filium Gemalli.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Asher, Sethur the son of Michael;
verses.textLa: De tribu Aser, Sthur filium Michael.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Naphtali, Nahbi the son of Vophsi;
verses.textLa: De tribu Nephthali, Nahabi filium Vapsi.

verses.textEn: from the tribe of Gad, Guel the son of Machi.
verses.textLa: De tribu Gad, Guel filium Machi.

verses.textEn: These are the names of the men, whom Moses sent to examine the land. And he called Hosea, the son of Nun, Joshua.
verses.textLa: Hæc sunt nomina virorum, quos misit Moyses ad considerandam Terram: vocavitque Osee filium Nun, Iosue.

verses.textEn: And so, Moses sent them to examine the land of Canaan, and he said to them: “Ascend by the south side. And when you arrive at the mountains,
verses.textLa: Misit ergo eos Moyses ad considerandam Terram Chanaan, et dixit ad eos: Ascendite per meridianam plagam. Cumque veneritis ad montes,

verses.textEn: consider the land, as to what kind it may be, and the people, who are its inhabitants, whether they may be strong or weak, whether they may be few in number or many,
verses.textLa: considerate Terram, qualis sit: et populum qui habitator est eius, utrum fortis sit an infirmus: si pauci numero an plures:

verses.textEn: and the land itself, whether it is good or bad, what kind of cities, walled or without walls,
verses.textLa: ipsa terra, bona an mala: urbes quales, muratæ an absque muris:

verses.textEn: the soil, rich or barren, forested or without trees. Be strong, and bring us some of the fruits of the land.” Now it was the time when the first ripe grapes were ready to be eaten.
verses.textLa: humus, pinguis an sterilis, nemorosa an absque arboribus. Confortamini, et afferte nobis de fructibus Terræ. Erat autem tempus quando iam præcoquæ uvæ vesci possunt.

verses.textEn: And when they had ascended, they explored the land from the desert of Sin, all the way to Rehob, as one enters into Hamath.
verses.textLa: Cumque ascendissent, exploraverunt Terram a deserto Sin, usque Rohob intrantibus Emath.

verses.textEn: And they ascended by the south side. And they arrived at Hebron, where there were Ahiman and Shishai and Talmai, the sons of Anak. For Hebron was founded seven years before Tanis, the city of Egypt.
verses.textLa: Ascenderuntque ad meridiem, et venerunt in Hebron, ubi erant Achiman et Sisai et Tholmai filii Enac. Nam Hebron septem annis ante Tanim urbem Ægypti condita est.

verses.textEn: And continuing on as far as the Torrent of the Cluster of Grapes, they cut off a vine with its grapes, which two men carried on a board. Likewise, they took from the pomegranates and the figs of that place,
verses.textLa: Pergentesque usque ad Torrentem Botri, absciderunt palmitem cum uva sua, quem portaverunt in vecte duo viri. De malis quoque granatis et de ficis loci illius tulerunt:

verses.textEn: which was called Nehel Eshcol, that is, the Torrent of the Cluster of Grapes, because the sons of Israel had carried a cluster of grapes from there.
verses.textLa: qui appellatus est Nehelescol, id est Torrens botri, eo quod botrum portassent inde filii Israel.

verses.textEn: And those exploring the land returned after forty days, having circulated through the entire region.
verses.textLa: Reversique exploratores Terræ post quadraginta dies, omni regione circuita,

verses.textEn: And they went to Moses and Aaron, and to the entire assembly of the sons of Israel in the desert of Paran, which is in Kadesh. And speaking to them, and to the entire multitude, they showed them the fruits of the land.
verses.textLa: venerunt ad Moysen et Aaron et ad omnem cœtum filiorum Israel in desertum Pharan, quod est in Cades. Locutique eis et omni multitudini ostenderunt fructus Terræ:

verses.textEn: And they explained, saying: “We went into the land, to which you sent us, which, it is true, flows with milk and honey, as one can know by these fruits.
verses.textLa: et narraverunt, dicentes: Venimus in Terram, ad quam misisti nos, quæ revera fluit lacte et melle, ut ex his fructibus cognosci potest:

verses.textEn: But it has very strong occupants, and the cities are great and also walled. We saw the race of Anak there.
verses.textLa: sed cultores fortissimos habet, et urbes grandes atque muratas. Stirpem Enac vidimus ibi.

verses.textEn: Amalek lives in the south. The Hethite, and the Jebusite, and the Amorite live in the mountains. And truly, the Canaanite stays near the sea and around the streams of the Jordan.”
verses.textLa: Amalec habitat in meridie, Hethæus et Iebusæus et Amorrhæus in montanis: Chananæus vero moratur iuxta mare et circa fluenta Iordanis.

verses.textEn: During these events, Caleb, to restrain the murmuring of the people who rose up against Moses, said, “Let us ascend and possess the land, for we will be able to obtain it.”
verses.textLa: Inter hæc Caleb compescens murmur populi, qui oriebatur contra Moysen, ait: Ascendamus, et possideamus Terram, quoniam poterimus obtinere eam.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the others, who had been with him, were saying, “By no means are we able to ascend to this people, because they are stronger than we are.”
verses.textLa: Alii vero, qui fuerant cum eo, dicebant: Nequaquam ad hunc populum valemus ascendere, quia fortior nobis est.

verses.textEn: And before the sons of Israel they disparaged the land, which they had inspected, saying: “The land, which we viewed, devours its inhabitants. The people, upon whom we gazed, were of lofty stature.
verses.textLa: Detraxeruntque Terræ, quam inspexerant, apud filios Israel, dicentes: Terra, quam lustravimus, devorat habitatores suos: populus, quem aspeximus, proceræ staturæ est.
verses.notes: Notice the contradiction in their words. The land is so harsh that it devours its inhabitants, yet these same inhabitants are described as if they were powerful giants.

verses.textEn: There, we saw some monsters among the sons of Anak, of the race of giants; by comparison with them, we seemed like locusts.”
verses.textLa: Ibi vidimus monstra quædam filiorum Enac de genere giganteo: quibus comparati, quasi locustæ videbamur.

verses.textEn: And so, crying out, the entire crowd wept throughout that night.
verses.textLa: Igitur vociferans omnis turba flevit nocte illa,

verses.textEn: And all the sons of Israel were murmuring against Moses and Aaron, saying:
verses.textLa: et murmurati sunt contra Moysen et Aaron cuncti filii Israel, dicentes:

verses.textEn: “If only we had died in Egypt,” and, “If only we would perish in this vast wilderness,” and, “May the Lord not lead us into this land, lest we fall by the sword, and our wives, as well as our children, be led away as captives. Is it not better to return to Egypt?”
verses.textLa: Utinam mortui essemus in Ægypto: et in hac vasta solitudine utinam pereamus, et non inducat nos Dominus in Terram istam, ne cadamus gladio, et uxores ac liberi nostri ducantur captivi. Nonne melius est reverti in Ægyptum?

verses.textEn: And they said to one another, “Let us appoint our leader, and so return to Egypt.”
verses.textLa: Dixeruntque alter ad alterum: Constituamus nobis ducem, et revertamur in Ægyptum.
verses.notes: This event foreshadows times in the Church when some of the faithful are of a mind to slide back towards sin, because they find being virtuous so difficult. A leader appointed in opposition to Moses, to lead the people back to Egypt, is analogous to an antipope.

verses.textEn: And when Moses and Aaron heard this, they fell prone on the ground in the sight of the multitude of the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Quo audito Moyses et Aaron ceciderunt proni in terram coram omni multitudine filiorum Israel.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Joshua the son of Nun, and Caleb the son of Jephunneh, who themselves had also viewed the land, tore their garments,
verses.textLa: At vero Iosue filius Nun, et Caleb filius Iephone, qui et ipsi lustraverant terram, sciderunt vestimenta sua,

verses.textEn: and they said to the entire multitude of the sons of Israel: “The land that we circled through is very good.
verses.textLa: et ad omnem multitudinem filiorum Israel locuti sunt: Terra, quam circuivimus, valde bona est.

verses.textEn: If the Lord will be gracious to us, he will lead us into it, and he will give us the land flowing with milk and honey.
verses.textLa: Si propitius fuerit Dominus, inducet nos in eam, et tradet humum lacte et melle manantem.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to be rebellious against the Lord. And do not fear the people of this land, for, like bread, so are we able to devour them. All protection has withdrawn from them. The Lord is with us. Do not be afraid.”
verses.textLa: Nolite rebelles esse contra Dominum: neque timeatis populum terræ huius, quia sicut panem ita eos possumus devorare. Recessit ab eis omne præsidium: Dominus nobiscum est, nolite metuere.

verses.textEn: And when the entire multitude cried out, and they wanted to crush them with stones, the glory of the Lord appeared, over the roof of the covenant, to all the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Cumque clamaret omnis multitudo, et lapidibus eos vellet opprimere, apparuit gloria Domini super tectum fœderis cunctis filiis Israel.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses: “How long will this people disparage me? How long will they refuse to believe me, despite all the signs that I have wrought before them?
verses.textLa: Et dixit Dominus ad Moysen: Usquequo detrahet mihi populus iste? Quousque non credent mihi in omnibus signis, quæ feci coram eis?

verses.textEn: Therefore, I will strike them with a pestilence, and so I will consume them. But you I will make the ruler over a great nation, and one which is mightier than this one.”
verses.textLa: Feriam igitur eos pestilentia, atque consumam: te autem faciam principem super gentem magnam, et fortiorem quam hæc est.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to the Lord: “But then the Egyptians, from whose midst you led out this people,
verses.textLa: Et ait Moyses ad Dominum: Ut audiant Ægyptii, de quorum medio eduxisti populum istum,

verses.textEn: and the inhabitants of this land, who have heard that you, O Lord, are among this people, and that you are seen face to face, and that your cloud protects them, and that you go before them with a column of cloud by day, and a column of fire by night,
verses.textLa: et habitatores Terræ huius, qui audierunt quod tu Domine in populo isto sis, et facie videaris ad faciem, et nubes tua protegat illos, et in columna nubis præcedas eos per diem, et in columna ignis per noctem:

verses.textEn: may hear that you have killed so great a multitude, as if they were one man, and they may say:
verses.textLa: quod occideris tantam multitudinem quasi unum hominem, et dicant:

verses.textEn: ‘He was not able to lead the people into the land about which he had sworn. Therefore, he slew them in the wilderness.’
verses.textLa: Non poterat introducere populum in Terram, pro qua iuraverat: idcirco occidit eos in solitudine.

verses.textEn: Therefore, may the strength of the Lord be magnified, just as you swore, saying:
verses.textLa: Magnificetur ergo fortitudo Domini sicut iurasti, dicens:

verses.textEn: ‘The Lord is patient and full of mercy, taking away iniquity and wickedness, and forsaking no one who is harmless. He visits the sins of the fathers upon the sons, to the third and fourth generation.’
verses.textLa: Dominus patiens et multæ misericordiæ, auferens iniquitatem et scelera, nullumque innoxium derelinquens, qui visitas peccata patrum in filios in tertiam et quartam generationem.

verses.textEn: Forgive, I beg you, the sins of this people, according to the greatness of your mercy, just as you have been gracious to them in their journey from Egypt to this place.”
verses.textLa: Dimitte, obsecro, peccatum populi huius secundum magnitudinem misericordiæ tuæ, sicut propitius fuisti egredientibus de Ægypto usque ad locum istum.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said: “I have forgiven them according to your word.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus: Dimisi iuxta verbum tuum.

verses.textEn: Also, as I live, the entire world shall be filled with the glory of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Vivo ego: et implebitur gloria Domini universa terra.
verses.notes: This promise is fulfilled only after the Return of Christ, when He establishes His kingdom on earth for over a thousand years.

verses.textEn: And yet, all the men who have seen my majesty, and the signs that I have wrought in Egypt and in the wilderness, and who have tested me ten times already, and yet have not obeyed my voice,
verses.textLa: At tamen omnes homines qui viderunt maiestatem meam, et signa quæ feci in Ægypto et in solitudine, et tentaverunt me iam per decem vices, nec obedierunt voci meæ,

verses.textEn: these shall not see the land, about which I swore to their fathers, neither shall any of those who detracted me gaze upon it.
verses.textLa: non videbunt Terram pro qua iuravi patribus eorum, nec quisquam ex illis qui detraxit mihi, intuebitur eam.

verses.textEn: My servant Caleb, who, being full of another spirit, has followed me, I will lead into this land, through which he has wandered, and his offspring shall possess it.
verses.textLa: Servum meum Caleb, qui plenus alio spiritu secutus est me, inducam in Terram hanc, quam circuivit: et semen eius possidebit eam.

verses.textEn: For the Amalekites and the Canaanites live in the valleys. Tomorrow, move the camp and return into the wilderness, by the way of the Red Sea.”
verses.textLa: Quoniam Amalecites et Chananæus habitant in vallibus. Cras movete castra, et revertimini in solitudinem per viam Maris Rubri.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron, dicens:

verses.textEn: “How long will this very wicked multitude murmur against me? I have heard the complaints of the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Usquequo multitudo hæc pessima murmurat contra me? Querelas filiorum Israel audivi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, say to them: As I live, says the Lord, as you spoke in my hearing, so will I do to you.
verses.textLa: Dic ergo eis: Vivo ego, ait Dominus: sicut locuti estis audiente me, sic faciam vobis.

verses.textEn: In the wilderness, here shall your carcasses lie. All you who were numbered from twenty years and above, and who have murmured against me,
verses.textLa: In solitudine hac iacebunt cadavera vestra. Omnes qui numerati estis a viginti annis et supra, et murmurastis contra me,

verses.textEn: you shall not enter into the land, over which I lifted up my hand to cause you to live there, except Caleb the son of Jephunneh, and Joshua the son of Nun.
verses.textLa: non intrabitis Terram, super quam levavi manum meam ut habitare vos facerem, præter Caleb filium Iephone, et Iosue filium Nun.

verses.textEn: But your little ones, about whom you said that they would be a prey to the enemies, I will lead them in, so that they may see the land that has displeased you.
verses.textLa: Parvulos autem vestros, de quibus dixistis quod prædæ hostibus forent, introducam: ut videant Terram, quæ vobis displicuit.

verses.textEn: Your carcasses shall lie in the wilderness.
verses.textLa: Vestra cadavera iacebunt in solitudine.

verses.textEn: Your sons shall wander in the desert for forty years, and they shall bear your fornication, until the carcasses of their fathers are consumed in the desert.
verses.textLa: Filii vestri erunt vagi in deserto annis quadraginta, et portabunt fornicationem vestram, donec consumantur cadavera patrum in deserto,

verses.textEn: According to the number of the forty days, during which you examined the land, one year shall be charged for each day. And so, for forty years you shall take back your iniquities, and you shall know my retribution.
verses.textLa: iuxta numerum quadraginta dierum, quibus considerastis Terram: annus pro die imputabitur. Et quadraginta annis recipietis iniquitates vestras, et scietis ultionem meam:

verses.textEn: For just as I have spoken, so shall I do, to this entire most wicked multitude, which has risen up together against me. In the wilderness, here shall it fade away and die.”
verses.textLa: quoniam sicut locutus sum, ita faciam omni multitudini huic pessimæ, quæ consurrexit adversum me: in solitudine hac deficiet, et morietur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, all the men, whom Moses had sent to contemplate the land, and who, having returned, had caused the entire multitude to murmur against him, disparaging the land as if it were evil,
verses.textLa: Igitur omnes viri, quos miserat Moyses ad contemplandam Terram, et qui reversi murmurare fecerant contra eum omnem multitudinem, detrahentes Terræ quod esset mala,

verses.textEn: suffered death and were struck down in the sight of the Lord.
verses.textLa: mortui sunt atque percussi in conspectu Domini.

verses.textEn: But only Joshua the son of Nun, and Caleb the son of Jephunneh remained alive, out of all those who had journeyed to examine the land.
verses.textLa: Iosue autem filius Nun, et Caleb filius Iephone vixerunt ex omnibus, qui perrexerant ad considerandam Terram.

verses.textEn: And Moses spoke all these words to all the sons of Israel, and the people mourned exceedingly.
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Moyses universa verba hæc ad omnes filios Israel, et luxit populus nimis.

verses.textEn: And behold, rising up at first light, they climbed to the top of the mountain, and they said, “We are prepared to ascend to the place, about which the Lord has spoken, for we have sinned.”
verses.textLa: Et ecce mane primo surgentes ascenderunt verticem montis, atque dixerunt: Parati sumus ascendere ad locum, de quo Dominus locutus est: quia peccavimus.
verses.notes: The people climbed the mountain so as to continue into the Holy Land, for they incorrectly thought that if they admitted their sin, they would avoid the punishment for that sin.

verses.textEn: And Moses said to them: “Why do you transgress the word of the Lord, merely because it will not result in prosperity for you?
verses.textLa: Quibus Moyses: Cur, inquit, transgredimini verbum Domini, quod vobis non cedet in prosperum?

verses.textEn: Do not ascend, for the Lord is not with you, lest you be overthrown before your enemies.
verses.textLa: Nolite ascendere: non enim est Dominus vobiscum: ne corruatis coram inimicis vestris.

verses.textEn: The Amalekite and the Canaanite are before you, by whose sword you shall be ruined, for you were not willing to consent to the Lord, and so the Lord is not with you.”
verses.textLa: Amalecites et Chananæus ante vos sunt, quorum gladio corruetis, eo quod nolueritis acquiescere Domino, nec erit Dominus vobiscum.

verses.textEn: But they, having been darkened, ascended to the top of the mountain. But the ark of the testament of the Lord, and Moses, did not withdraw from the camp.
verses.textLa: At illi contenebrati ascenderunt in verticem montis. Arca autem testamenti Domini et Moyses non recesserunt de castris.

verses.textEn: And the Amalekites descended, along with those Canaanites who were living in the mountains. And so, striking and cutting them down, they pursued them all the way to Hormah.
verses.textLa: Descenditque Amalecites et Chananæus, qui habitabat in monte: et percutiens eos atque concidens, persecutus est eos usque Horma.

verses.textEn: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutus est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Speak to the sons of Israel, and you shall say to them: When you will have entered into the land of your habitation, which I will give you,
verses.textLa: Loquere ad filios Israel, et dices ad eos: Cum ingressi fueritis Terram habitationis vestræ, quam ego dabo vobis,

verses.textEn: and you make an offering to the Lord, as a holocaust or as a victim, paying your vows, or as a voluntary offering of gifts, or in your solemnities, burning a sweet odor to the Lord, whether from the oxen or from the sheep:
verses.textLa: et feceritis oblationem Domino in holocaustum, aut victimam, vota solventes, vel sponte offerentes munera, aut in sollemnitatibus vestris adolentes odorem suavitatis Domino, de bobus sive de ovibus:

verses.textEn: whoever immolates the victim shall offer a sacrifice of fine wheat flour, the tenth part of an ephah, sprinkled with oil, which shall have the measure of the fourth part of a hin,
verses.textLa: offeret quicumque immolaverit victimam, sacrificium similæ, decimam partem ephi, conspersæ oleo, quod mensuram habebit quartam partem hin:

verses.textEn: and he shall give the same measure of wine, poured out as libations, whether as a holocaust or as a victim.
verses.textLa: et vinum ad liba fundenda eiusdem mensuræ dabit in holocaustum sive in victimam.

verses.textEn: With each lamb and each ram, there shall be a sacrifice of fine wheat flour, of two tenths, which shall be sprinkled with one third part of a hin of oil.
verses.textLa: Per agnos singulos et arietes erit sacrificium similæ duarum decimarum, quæ conspersa sit oleo tertiæ partis hin:

verses.textEn: And he shall offer the same measure, one third part of wine, for the libation, as a sweet odor to the Lord.
verses.textLa: et vinum ad libamentum tertiæ partis eiusdem mensuræ offeret in odorem suavitatis Domino.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, when you will offer, from the oxen, a holocaust or a victim, in order to fulfill your vow or for peace-offering victims,
verses.textLa: Quando vero de bobus feceris holocaustum aut hostiam, ut impleas votum vel pacificas victimas,

verses.textEn: you shall give, for each ox, three tenths of fine wheat flour, sprinkled with oil, which has the measure of one half of one hin,
verses.textLa: dabis per singulos boves similæ tres decimas conspersæ oleo, quod habeat medium mensuræ hin:

verses.textEn: and the wine, poured out as libations, shall be of the same measure, as an oblation of most sweet odor to the Lord.
verses.textLa: et vinum ad liba fundenda eiusdem mensuræ in oblationem suavissimi odoris Domino.

verses.textEn: So shall you do
verses.textLa: Sic facies

verses.textEn: for each ox, and ram, and lamb, and young goat.
verses.textLa: per singulos boves et arietis et agnos et hœdos.

verses.textEn: Both natives and sojourners
verses.textLa: Tam indigenæ quam peregrini

verses.textEn: shall offer sacrifices by the same rituals.
verses.textLa: eodem ritu offerent sacrificia.

verses.textEn: There shall be one precept and one judgment, as much for yourselves as for newcomers to the land.”
verses.textLa: Unum præceptum erit atque iudicium tam vobis quam advenis terræ.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutus est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Speak to the sons of Israel, and you shall say to them:
verses.textLa: Loquere filiis Israel, et dices ad eos:

verses.textEn: When you will arrive in the land which I will give to you,
verses.textLa: Cum veneritis in terram, quam dabo vobis,

verses.textEn: and when you will eat from the bread of that region, you shall separate the first-fruits to the Lord
verses.textLa: et comederitis de panibus regionis illius, separabitis primitias Domino

verses.textEn: from the foods that you eat. Just as you separate the first-fruits of your threshing floors,
verses.textLa: de cibis vestris. Sicut de areis primitias separatis,

verses.textEn: so also shall you give the first-fruits of your cooked grains to the Lord.
verses.textLa: ita et de pulmentis dabitis primitiva Domino.

verses.textEn: And if, through ignorance, you neglect any of these things, which the Lord has spoken to Moses,
verses.textLa: Quod si per ignorantiam præterieritis quidquam horum, quæ locutus est Dominus ad Moysen,
verses.notes: The term ‘ignorantiam’ in this context includes not only initial ignorance of the precept, but also ignoring or forgetting a known precept.

verses.textEn: and which he has commanded through him for you, from the day that he began to command and thereafter,
verses.textLa: et mandavit per eum ad vos, a die qua cœpit iubere et ultra,

verses.textEn: and if the multitude will have forgotten to do it, then they shall offer a calf from the herd, a holocaust as a most sweet odor to the Lord, and its sacrifice and libations, just as the ceremonies ask, and a he-goat for sin.
verses.textLa: oblitaque fuerit facere multitudo: offeret vitulum de armento, holocaustum in odorem suavissimum Domino, et sacrificum eius ac liba, ut ceremoniæ postulant, hircumque pro peccato:

verses.textEn: And the priest shall pray for the entire multitude of the sons of Israel, and it shall be forgiven them, because they did not sin willfully. Nevertheless, they shall offer incense to the Lord for themselves, and for sin, as well as for their error.
verses.textLa: et rogabit sacerdos pro omni multitudine filiorum Israel: et dimittetur eis, quoniam non sponte peccaverunt, nihilominus offerentes incensum Domino pro se et pro peccato atque errore suo:

verses.textEn: And it shall be forgiven all the people of the sons of Israel, as well as the newcomers who sojourn among them, for it is the culpability of all the people through neglect.
verses.textLa: et dimittetur universæ plebi filiorum Israel, et advenis, qui peregrinantur inter eos: quoniam culpa est omnis populi per ignorantiam.
verses.notes: The ignorance spoken of in this verse is not pure ignorance, but also includes some culpability, due to neglect.

verses.textEn: But if one soul will have sinned by not knowing, he shall offer a one-year-old she-goat for his sin.
verses.textLa: Quod si anima una nesciens peccaverit, offeret capram anniculam pro peccato suo:

verses.textEn: And the priest shall pray for him, because he sinned unknowingly before the Lord. And he shall obtain pardon for him, and it will be forgiven him.
verses.textLa: et deprecabitur pro ea sacerdos, quod inscia peccaverit coram Domino: impetrabitque ei veniam, et dimittetur illi.

verses.textEn: One law shall be for all who sin by ignorance, as much for natives as for newcomers.
verses.textLa: Tam indigenis quam advenis una lex erit omnium, qui peccaverint ignorantes.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the soul who commits any of these acts through arrogance, whether he is a citizen or a sojourner, because he has rebelled against the Lord, shall perish from among his people.
verses.textLa: Anima vero, quæ per superbiam aliquid commiserit, sive civis sit ille, sive peregrinus, (quoniam adversus Dominum rebellis fuit) peribit de populo suo:

verses.textEn: For he has despised the word of the Lord, and he has nullified his precept. For this reason, he shall be destroyed, and he shall bear his iniquity.”
verses.textLa: verbum enim Domini contempsit, et præceptum illius fecit irritum: idcirco delebitur, et portabit iniquitatem suam.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when the sons of Israel were in the wilderness, and they had found a man collecting wood on the day of the Sabbath,
verses.textLa: Factum est autem, cum essent filii Israel in solitudine, et invenissent hominem colligentem ligna in die Sabbati,

verses.textEn: they brought him to Moses and Aaron, and to the whole multitude.
verses.textLa: obtulerunt eum Moysi et Aaron et universæ multitudini.

verses.textEn: And they enclosed him in a prison, not knowing what they should do with him.
verses.textLa: Qui recluserunt eum in carcerem, nescientes quid super eo facere deberent.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses, “Let that man be put to death; let the entire crowd crush him with stones, outside the camp.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Morte moriatur homo iste, obruat eum lapidibus omnis turba extra castra.

verses.textEn: And when they had led him out, they overwhelmed him with stones, and he died, just as the Lord had instructed.
verses.textLa: Cumque eduxissent eum foras, obruerunt lapidibus, et mortuus est, sicut præceperat Dominus.

verses.textEn: The Lord also said to Moses:
verses.textLa: Dixit quoque Dominus ad Moysen:

verses.textEn: “Speak to the sons of Israel, and you shall tell them to make for themselves hems at the corners of their cloaks, placing in them ribbons of hyacinth,
verses.textLa: Loquere filiis Israel, et dices ad eos ut faciant sibi fimbrias per angulos palliorum, ponentes in eis vittas hyacinthinas:
