verses.textEn: so that, when they see these, they may remember all the commandments of the Lord, and they may not follow their own thoughts and eyes, fornicating in various ways,
verses.textLa: quas cum viderint, recordentur omnium mandatorum Domini, nec sequantur cogitationes suas et oculos per res varias fornicantes,

verses.textEn: but instead, they, being more mindful of the precepts of the Lord, may do them and may be holy to their God.
verses.textLa: sed magis memores præceptorum Domini faciant ea, sintque sancti Deo suo.

verses.textEn: I am the Lord your God, who led you away from the land of Egypt, so that I may be your God.”
verses.textLa: Ego Dominus Deus vester, qui eduxi vos de Terra Ægypti, ut essem Deus vester.

verses.textEn: Then, behold, Korah the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, with Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and also On the son of Peleth, of the sons of Ruben,
verses.textLa: Ecce autem Core filius Isaar, filii Caath, filii Levi, et Dathan atque Abiron filii Eliab, Hon quoque filius Pheleth de filiis Ruben,

verses.textEn: rose up against Moses, with two hundred fifty others of the sons of Israel, leading men of the assembly, and who, at the time of a council, would be called by name.
verses.textLa: surrexerunt contra Moysen, aliique filiorum Israel ducenti quinquaginta viri proceres synagogæ, et qui tempore concilii per nomina vocabantur.

verses.textEn: And when they had stood against Moses and Aaron, they said: “Let it be sufficient for you that the entire multitude is of holy ones, and that the Lord is among them. Why do you elevate yourselves above the people of the Lord?”
verses.textLa: Cumque stetissent adversum Moysen et Aaron, dixerunt: Sufficiat vobis, quia omnis multitudo sanctorum est, et in ipsis est Dominus: Cur elevamini super populum Domini?
verses.notes: This event foreshadows times in the Church when religious will try to claim that all are equal and so all should have the same role; thus will they claim that they should act as only the ordained can act, even to attempting the Sacraments. They will detract from the roles and authority and ability given to the Pope, and to the body of Bishops united with him, and to ordained persons in general.

verses.textEn: When Moses had heard this, he fell prone on his face.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset Moyses, cecidit pronus in faciem:

verses.textEn: And speaking to Korah, and to the entire multitude, he said: “In the morning, the Lord will cause it to be known who belongs to him, and which holy ones he will join to himself. And whomever he will choose, they shall be close to him.
verses.textLa: locutusque ad Core et ad omnem multitudinem: Mane, inquit, notum faciet Dominus qui ad se pertineant, et sanctos applicabit sibi: et quos elegerit, appropinquabunt ei.

verses.textEn: Therefore, do this: Each one of you, Korah and all your associates, take your censer,
verses.textLa: Hoc igitur facite: Tollat unusquisque thuribula sua, tu Core, et omne concilium tuum:

verses.textEn: and drawing fire into it tomorrow, place incense upon it before the Lord. And whomever he will choose, the same shall be holy. You sons of Levi have been raised up greatly.”
verses.textLa: et hausto cras igne, ponite desuper thymiama coram Domino: et quemcumque elegerit, ipse erit sanctus: multum erigimini filii Levi.

verses.textEn: And he said again to Korah: “Listen, sons of Levi.
verses.textLa: Dixitque rursum ad Core: Audite filii Levi:

verses.textEn: Is it a small thing to you, that the God of Israel has separated you from all the people, and has joined you to himself, so that you would serve him in the rituals of the tabernacle, and stand before gatherings of the people, and minister to him?
verses.textLa: Num parum vobis est quod separavit vos Deus Israel ab omni populo, et iunxit sibi, ut serviretis ei in cultu tabernaculi, et staretis coram frequentia populi, et ministraretis ei?

verses.textEn: Was the reason that he caused you and all your brothers, the sons of Levi, to approach him, so that you would even claim for yourselves the priesthood too,
verses.textLa: idcirco ad se fecit accedere te et omnes fratres tuos filios Levi, ut vobis etiam sacerdotium vindicetis,

verses.textEn: and so that your entire group would stand against the Lord? For what is Aaron that you should murmur against him?”
verses.textLa: et omnis globus tuus stet contra Dominum? Quid est enim Aaron ut murmuretis contra eum?

verses.textEn: Therefore, Moses sent to call for Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, who responded: “We will not come.
verses.textLa: Misit ergo Moyses ut vocaret Dathan et Abiron filios Eliab. Qui responderunt: Non venimus.

verses.textEn: Is it a small matter to you, that you have led us away from a land that was flowing with milk and honey, so as to kill us in the desert, unless you could also be a ruler over us?
verses.textLa: Numquid parum est tibi quod eduxisti nos de terra, quæ lacte et melle manabat, ut occideres in deserto, nisi et dominatus fueris nostri?

verses.textEn: You have led us, it is true, to a land that flows with streams of milk and honey, and you have given us possession of fields and vineyards. But will you also tear out our eyes? We will not come.”
verses.textLa: Revera induxisti nos in terram, quæ fluit rivis lactis et mellis, et dedisti nobis possessiones agrorum et vinearum. An et oculos nostros vis eruere? Non venimus.

verses.textEn: And Moses, being very angry, said to the Lord: “Do not look with favor on their sacrifices. You know that I have not accepted from them, at any time, so much as a young donkey, nor have I afflicted any of them.”
verses.textLa: Iratusque Moyses valde, ait ad Dominum: Ne respicias sacrificia eorum: tu scis quod ne asellum quidem umquam acceperim ab eis, nec afflixerim quempiam eorum.

verses.textEn: And he said to Korah: “You and your congregation, stand alone before the Lord, and apart from Aaron, tomorrow.
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad Core: Tu, et omnis congregatio tua, state seorsum coram Domino, et Aaron die crastino separatim.

verses.textEn: Let each one of you take censers, and place incense in them, offering to the Lord two hundred fifty censers. Let Aaron also hold his censer.”
verses.textLa: Tollite singuli thuribula vestra, et ponite super ea incensum, offerentes Domino ducenta quinquaginta thuribula: Aaron quoque teneat thuribulum suum.

verses.textEn: When they had done this, Moses and Aaron stood up,
verses.textLa: Quod cum fecissent, stantibus Moyses et Aaron,

verses.textEn: and, having crowded the entire multitude close to them at the door of the tabernacle, the glory of the Lord appeared to them all.
verses.textLa: et coacervassent adversum eos omnem multitudinem ad ostium tabernaculi, apparuit cunctis gloria Domini.

verses.textEn: And the Lord, speaking to Moses and Aaron, said:
verses.textLa: Locutusque Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron, ait:

verses.textEn: “Separate yourselves from the midst of this congregation, so that I may suddenly destroy them.”
verses.textLa: Separamini de medio congregationis huius, ut eos repente disperdam.

verses.textEn: But they fell prone on their faces, and they said, “O most strong One, the God of the spirits of all flesh, should your anger rage against all, for the sin of one?”
verses.textLa: Qui ceciderunt proni in faciem, atque dixerunt: Fortissime Deus spirituum universæ carnis, num uno peccante, contra omnes ira tua desæviet?

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses:
verses.textLa: Et ait Dominus ad Moysen:

verses.textEn: “Instruct the entire people to separate from the tents of Korah, and Dathan, and Abiram.”
verses.textLa: Præcipe universo populo ut separetur a tabernaculis Core, et Dathan et Abiron.

verses.textEn: And Moses rose up and went to Dathan and Abiram. And the elders of Israel followed him,
verses.textLa: Surrexitque Moyses, et abiit ad Dathan et Abiron: et sequentibus eum senioribus Israel,

verses.textEn: and he said to the crowd, “Withdraw from the tabernacles of these impious men, and touch nothing which pertains to them, lest you become involved in their sins.”
verses.textLa: dixit ad turbam: Recedite a tabernaculis hominum impiorum, et nolite tangere quæ ad eos pertinent, ne involvamini in peccatis eorum.

verses.textEn: And when they had withdrawn from their tents all around, Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the entrance of their pavilions, with their wives and children, and with all their associates.
verses.textLa: Cumque recessissent a tentoriis eorum per circuitum, Dathan et Abiron egressi stabant in introitu papilionum suorum cum uxoribus et liberis, omnique frequentia.

verses.textEn: And Moses said: “By this shall you know that the Lord has sent me to do all that you discern, and that I have not brought these things out of my own heart:
verses.textLa: Et ait Moyses: In hoc scietis, quod Dominus miserit me ut facerem universa quæ cernitis, et non ex proprio ea corde protulerim:

verses.textEn: If these men pass away by the common death of men, or if they will be visited by a scourge, of a kind by which others are often visited, then the Lord did not send me.
verses.textLa: Si consueta hominum morte interierint, et visitaverit eos plaga, qua et ceteri visitari solent, non misit me Dominus:

verses.textEn: But if the Lord accomplishes something new, so that the earth opens its mouth and swallows them whole, along with everything that belongs to them, and they descend alive into the underworld, then you shall know that they have blasphemed the Lord.”
verses.textLa: sin autem novam rem fecerit Dominus, ut aperiens terra os suum deglutiat eos et omnia quæ ad illos pertinent, descenderintque viventes in infernum, scietis quod blasphemaverint Dominum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, as soon as he had ceased to speak, the earth broke open under their feet.
verses.textLa: Confestim igitur ut cessavit loqui, dirupta est terra sub pedibus eorum:

verses.textEn: And opening its mouth, it devoured them with their tabernacles and their entire substance.
verses.textLa: et aperiens os suum, devoravit illos cum tabernaculis suis et universa substantia eorum.

verses.textEn: And they descended alive, the ground closing around them, into the underworld, and they perished from the midst of the multitude.
verses.textLa: Descenderuntque vivi in infernum operti humo, et perierunt de medio multitudinis.
verses.notes: Scripture is not saying that they went to Hell alive, without ever dying, but rather that they were alive when swallowed up by the ground. Thereafter they died, and perhaps they, or some of theirs, went to Hell.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, all of Israel, which was standing all around, took flight at the clamor of those who were perishing, saying, “Lest perhaps the earth may swallow us whole also.”
verses.textLa: At vero omnis Israel, qui stabat per gyrum, fugit ad clamorem pereuntium, dicens: Ne forte et nos terra deglutiat.

verses.textEn: Then, too, a fire, going forth from the Lord, put to death the two hundred fifty men who were offering the incense.
verses.textLa: Sed et ignis egressus a Domino, interfecit ducentos quinquaginta viros, qui offerebant incensum.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Instruct Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, to take up the censers which lie in the burning, and to scatter the fire to one side and another, because they were sanctified
verses.textLa: Præcipe Eleazaro filio Aaron sacerdoti ut tollat thuribula quæ iacent in incendio, et ignem huc illucque dispergat: quoniam sanctificata sunt

verses.textEn: in the deaths of these sinners. And let him form them into plates, and affix them to the altar, because incense had been offered in them to the Lord, and they were sanctified, and so that the sons of Israel may discern in them a sign and a memorial.”
verses.textLa: in mortibus peccatorum: producatque ea in laminas, et affigat altari, eo quod oblatum sit in eis incensum Domino, et sanctificata sint, ut cernant ea pro signo et monimento filii Israel.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Eleazar the priest took the bronze censers, by which those whom the burning devoured had made an offering, and he formed them into plates, affixing them to the altar,
verses.textLa: Tulit ergo Eleazar sacerdos thuribula ænea, in quibus obtulerant hi quos incendium devoravit, et produxit ea in laminas, affigens altari:

verses.textEn: so that the sons of Israel would have, thereafter, something to admonish them, lest any stranger, or anyone who is not of the offspring of Aaron, might approach to offer incense to the Lord, and lest he endure what happened to Korah, and to all his congregation, when the Lord spoke to Moses.
verses.textLa: ut haberent postea filii Israel, quibus commonerentur ne quis accedat alienigena, et qui non est de semine Aaron ad offerendum incensum Domino, ne patiatur sicut passus est Core, et omnis congregatio eius, loquente Domino ad Moysen.

verses.textEn: Then, the following day, the entire multitude of the sons of Israel murmured against Moses and Aaron, saying: “You have put to death the people of the Lord.”
verses.textLa: Murmuravit autem omnis multitudo filiorum Israel sequenti die contra Moysen et Aaron, dicens: Vos interfecistis populum Domini.

verses.textEn: And when there arose a sedition, and the tumult increased,
verses.textLa: Cumque oriretur seditio, et tumultus incresceret,

verses.textEn: Moses and Aaron fled to the tabernacle of the covenant. But after they had entered it, the cloud covered it, and the glory of the Lord appeared.
verses.textLa: Moyses et Aaron fugerunt ad tabernaculum fœderis. Quod, postquam ingressi sunt, operuit nubes, et apparuit gloria Domini.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses:
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen:

verses.textEn: “Withdraw from the midst of this multitude, and I will destroy them immediately.” And while they were lying on the ground,
verses.textLa: Recedite de medio huius multitudinis, etiam nunc delebo eos. Cumque iacerent in terra,

verses.textEn: Moses said to Aaron: “Take the censer, and draw fire into it from the altar; place incense upon it, and continue on, quickly, to the people, to pray for them. For already wrath has gone forth from the Lord, and the scourge rages.”
verses.textLa: dixit Moyses ad Aaron: Tolle thuribulum, et hausto igne de altari, mitte incensum desuper, pergens cito ad populum ut roges pro eis: iam enim egressa est ira a Domino, et plaga desævit.

verses.textEn: When Aaron had done this, and he had run into the midst of the multitude, which the burning fire was now destroying, he offered the incense.
verses.textLa: Quod cum fecisset Aaron, et cucurrisset ad mediam multitudinem, quam iam vastabat incendium, obtulit thymiama:

verses.textEn: And standing between the dead and the living, he prayed for the people, and the scourge ceased.
verses.textLa: et stans inter mortuos ac viventes, pro populo deprecatus est, et plaga cessavit.

verses.textEn: But the number of those who were struck down was fourteen thousand men, and seven hundred, aside from those who had perished in the sedition of Korah.
verses.textLa: Fuerunt autem qui percussi sunt, quattuordecim millia hominum, et septingenti, absque his qui perierant in seditione Core.

verses.textEn: And Aaron returned to Moses at the door of the tabernacle of the covenant, after the destruction quieted.
verses.textLa: Reversusque est Aaron ad Moysen ad ostium tabernaculi fœderis postquam quievit interitus.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Et locutus est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Speak to the sons of Israel, and receive from each of them a rod by their kinships, from all the leaders of the tribes, twelve rods, and write the name of each one on his rod.
verses.textLa: Loquere ad filios Israel, et accipe ab eis virgas singulas per cognationes suas, a cunctis principibus tribuum, virgas duodecim, et uniuscuiusque nomen superscribes virgæ suæ.

verses.textEn: But the name of Aaron shall be for the tribe of Levi, and one rod separately shall contain all their families.
verses.textLa: Nomen autem Aaron erit in tribu Levi, et una virga cunctas seorsum familias continebit:

verses.textEn: And you shall place these in the tabernacle of the covenant before the testimony, where I will speak to you.
verses.textLa: ponesque eas in tabernaculo fœderis coram testimonio, ubi loquar ad te.

verses.textEn: Whomever of these I will choose, his rod will germinate, and so shall I restrain the complaints of the sons of Israel before me, by which they murmur against you.”
verses.textLa: Quem ex his elegero, germinabit virga eius: et cohibebo a me querimonias filiorum Israel, quibus contra vos murmurant.

verses.textEn: And Moses spoke to the sons of Israel. And all the leaders gave him rods, one for each tribe. And there were twelve rods, aside from the rod of Aaron.
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Moyses ad filios Israel: et dederunt ei omnes principes virgas per singulas tribus: fueruntque virgæ duodecim absque virga Aaron.

verses.textEn: And when Moses had placed these before the Lord, in the tabernacle of the testimony,
verses.textLa: Quas cum posuisset Moyses coram Domino in tabernaculo testimonii:

verses.textEn: returning on the following day, he found that the rod of Aaron for the house of Levi, had germinated, and that the swelling buds had opened into flowers, which, spreading their petals, were formed into those of an almond tree.
verses.textLa: sequenti die regressus invenit germinasse virgam Aaron in domo Levi: et turgentibus gemmis eruperant flores, qui, foliis dilatatis, in amygdalas deformati sunt.
verses.notes: Do the flower petals have the shape of almonds, or are these flowers like those of an almond tree? The former does not fit this verse because the form refers to the flowers, once their petals have opened, not to the petals themselves. Also, it seems that it would not be worthy of a remark by Scripture if it was merely the case that the petals had an almond shape. But if these are almond tree blossoms, then there may be a symbolic meaning (since almond trees are mentioned elsewhere in Scripture (Genesis, Ecclesiastes).

verses.textEn: Therefore, Moses brought out all the rods, from the sight of the Lord, to all the sons of Israel. And they saw, and each one received their rods.
verses.textLa: Protulit ergo Moyses omnes virgas de conspectu Domini ad cunctos filios Israel: videruntque et receperunt singuli virgas suas.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses: “Carry back the rod of Aaron into the tabernacle of the testimony, so that it may be kept there as a sign of the rebellion of the sons of Israel, and so that their complaints may be quieted before me, lest they die.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Refer virgam Aaron in tabernaculum testimonii, ut servetur ibi in signum rebellium filiorum Israel, et quiescant querelæ eorum a me, ne moriantur.

verses.textEn: And Moses did just as the Lord had instructed.
verses.textLa: Fecitque Moyses sicut præceperat Dominus.

verses.textEn: Then the sons of Israel said to Moses: “Behold, we have been consumed; we have been ruined.
verses.textLa: Dixerunt autem filii Israel ad Moysen: Ecce consumpti sumus, omnes perivimus.

verses.textEn: Whoever approaches to the tabernacle of the Lord dies. Will we all be wiped away, even to total annihilation?”
verses.textLa: Quicumque accedit ad tabernaculum Domini, moritur. Num usque ad internecionem cuncti delendi sumus?

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Aaron: “You, and your sons, and the house of your father with you, shall carry the iniquity of the Sanctuary. And you and your sons together shall bear the sins of your priesthood.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Aaron: Tu, et filii tui, et domus patris tui tecum portabitis iniquitatem Sanctuarii: et tu et filii tui simul sustinebitis peccata sacerdotii vestri.

verses.textEn: But take to yourselves also your brothers from the tribe of Levi, and the scepter of your father, and may they be prepared, and may they minister to you. Then you and your sons shall minister in the tabernacle of the testimony.
verses.textLa: Sed et fratres tuos de tribu Levi, et sceptrum patris tui sume tecum, præstoque sint, et ministrent tibi: tu autem et filii tui ministrabitis in tabernaculo testimonii.

verses.textEn: And the Levites shall stand watch by your precepts, and for all the works of the tabernacle; yet in such a manner that they shall not approach the vessels of the Sanctuary and of the altar, lest both they die, and you perish, at the same time.
verses.textLa: Excubabuntque Levitæ ad præcepta tua, et ad cuncta opera tabernaculi: ita dumtaxat, ut ad vasa Sanctuarii et ad altare non accedant, ne et illi moriantur, et vos pereatis simul.
verses.notes: This verse teaches a necessary and perpetual distinction between the ordained clergy and non-ordained religious.

verses.textEn: But they may be with you, and they may watch over the care of the tabernacle and all its ceremonies. A foreigner shall not be mixed with you.
verses.textLa: Sint autem tecum, et excubent in custodiis tabernaculi, et in omnibus cæremoniis eius. Alienigena non miscebitur vobis.

verses.textEn: Watch over the care of the Sanctuary, and over the ministry of the altar, lest an indignation may rise over the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Excubate in custodia Sanctuarii, et in ministerio altaris: ne oriatur indignatio super filios Israel.

verses.textEn: I have given your brothers, the Levites, to you from the midst of the sons of Israel, and I have delivered them as a gift to the Lord, in order to serve in the ministries of his tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Ego dedi vobis fratres vestros Levitas de medio filiorum Israel, et tradidi donum Domino, ut serviant in ministeriis tabernaculi eius.

verses.textEn: But as for you and your sons: guard the priesthood. For all that pertains to the service of the altar and of what is beyond the veil shall be exercised by the priests. If any outsider will approach, he shall be killed.”
verses.textLa: Tu autem et filii tui custodite sacerdotium vestrum: et omnia quæ ad cultum altaris pertinent, et intra velum sunt, per sacerdotes administrabuntur. Si quis externus accesserit, occidetur.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Aaron: “Behold, I have given you custody of my first-fruits. Everything that is sanctified by the sons of Israel I have delivered to you and your sons, for the office of the priesthood, by everlasting ordinances.
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Aaron: Ecce dedi tibi custodiam primitiarum mearum. Omnia quæ sanctificantur a filiis Israel, tradidi tibi et filiis tuis pro officio sacerdotali legitima sempiterna.

verses.textEn: Therefore, you shall receive these, from the things that are sanctified and offered to the Lord. Every offering, and sacrifice, and whatever is repaid to me, on behalf of sin and also for offenses, and which becomes the Holy of holies, shall be for you and for your sons.
verses.textLa: Hæc ergo accipies de his, quæ sanctificantur et oblata sunt Domino. Omnis oblatio, et sacrificium, et quidquid pro peccato atque delicto redditur mihi, et cedit in Sancta sanctorum, tuum erit, et filiorum tuorum.

verses.textEn: You shall eat it in the Sanctuary. Only the males shall eat from it, because it has been consecrated for you.
verses.textLa: In Sanctuario comedes illud: mares tantum edent ex eo, quia consecratum est tibi.

verses.textEn: But the first-fruits, which the sons of Israel shall vow and offer, I have given to you, and to your sons, as well as to your daughters, by a perpetual right. Whoever is clean in your house shall eat them.
verses.textLa: Primitias autem, quas voverint et obtulerint filii Israel, tibi dedi, et filiis tuis, ac filiabus tuis iure perpetuo. Qui mundus est in domo tua, vescetur eis.

verses.textEn: All the innermost of the oil, and of the wine, and of the grain, whatever first-fruits they offer to the Lord, I have given to you.
verses.textLa: Omnem medullam olei, et vini, ac frumenti, quidquid offerunt primitiarum Domino, tibi dedi.

verses.textEn: All the first of the crops, which the soil produces and which are carried to the Lord, shall fall to your use. Whoever is clean in your house shall eat them.
verses.textLa: Universa frugum initia, quas gignit humus, et Domino deportantur, cedent in usus tuos: qui mundus est in domo tua, vescetur eis.

verses.textEn: All that the sons of Israel shall repay by vow shall be yours.
verses.textLa: Omne quod ex voto reddiderint filii Israel, tuum erit.

verses.textEn: Whatever goes out first from the womb, of all flesh, which they offer to the Lord, whether from men or from cattle, shall be your right; yet only in so far as, for the firstborn of man, you shall accept a price. And every animal that is unclean you shall cause to be redeemed.
verses.textLa: Quidquid primum erumpit e vulva cunctæ carnis, quam offerunt Domino, sive ex hominibus, sive de pecoribus fuerit, tui iuris erit: ita dumtaxat, ut pro hominis primogenito pretium accipias, et omne animal quod immundum est, redimi facias,

verses.textEn: And its redemption shall be, after one month, five shekels of silver, by the weight of the Sanctuary. A shekel has twenty obols.
verses.textLa: cuius redemptio erit post unum mensem, siclis argenti quinque, pondere Sanctuarii. Siclus viginti obolos habet.

verses.textEn: But the firstborn of a cow, or of a sheep, or of a goat, you shall not cause to be redeemed, because they have been sanctified to the Lord. Thus, their blood you shall pour out upon the altar, and their fat you shall burn as a most sweet odor to the Lord.
verses.textLa: Primogenitum autem bovis et ovis et capræ non facies redimi, quia sanctificata sunt Domino. Sanguinem tantum eorum fundes super altare, et adipes adolebis in suavissimum odorem Domino.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the flesh shall fall to your use, just as the consecrated breast and the right shoulder shall be yours.
verses.textLa: Carnes vero in usum tuum cedent, sicut pectusculum consecratum, et armus dexter, tua erunt.

verses.textEn: All the first-fruits of the Sanctuary, which the sons of Israel offer to the Lord, I have given to you and to your sons as well as to your daughters, as a perpetual right. It is an everlasting covenant of salt before the Lord, for you and for your sons.”
verses.textLa: Omnes primitias Sanctuarii, quas offerunt filii Israel Domino, tibi dedi et filiis, ac filiabus tuis iure perpetuo. Pactum salis est sempiternum coram Domino, tibi ac filiis tuis.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Aaron: “In their land, you shall possess nothing; neither shall you have a portion among them. I am your portion and your inheritance in the midst of the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Aaron: In terra eorum nihil possidebitis, nec habebitis partem inter eos: ego pars et hereditas tua in medio filiorum Israel.

verses.textEn: But I have given, to the sons of Levi, all the tithes of Israel as a possession, for the ministry by which they serve me in the tabernacle of the covenant,
verses.textLa: Filiis autem Levi dedi omnes decimas Israelis in possessionem pro ministerio quo serviunt mihi in tabernaculo fœderis:

verses.textEn: so that the sons of Israel may no longer approach to the tabernacle, nor commit deadly sin.
verses.textLa: ut non accedant ultra filii Israel ad tabernaculum, nec committant peccatum mortiferum:

verses.textEn: Only the sons of Levi may serve me in the tabernacle and may carry the sins of the people. It shall be an everlasting ordinance in your generations. They shall possess nothing else;
verses.textLa: solis filiis Levi mihi in tabernaculo servientibus, et portantibus peccata populi. Legitimum sempiternum erit in generationibus vestris. Nihil aliud possidebunt,
verses.notes: Here is one verse of Scripture, among many others, which supports the taking of a vow of poverty by priests and religious.

verses.textEn: being content with the oblation of tithes, which I have separated for their uses and necessities.”
verses.textLa: decimarum oblatione contenti, quas in usus eorum et necessaria separavi.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Instruct the Levites, and also declare to them: When you will receive, from the sons of Israel, the tithes, which I have given to you, offer their first-fruits to the Lord, that is, the tenth part of a tenth,
verses.textLa: Præcipe Levitis, atque denuncia: Cum acceperitis a filiis Israel decimas, quas dedi vobis, primitias earum offerte Domino, id est, decimam partem decimæ,

verses.textEn: so that it may be accounted to you as an oblation of the first-fruits, as much from the threshing floors as from the oil and wine presses.
verses.textLa: ut reputetur vobis in oblationem primitivorum, tam de areis quam de torcularibus:
verses.notes: The word ‘torcularibus’ is not specific to wine presses; both oil and wine were certainly subject to tithes; therefore, the translation takes this meaning into account.

verses.textEn: And offer the first-fruits of everything, from which you receive tithes, to the Lord, and give them to Aaron the priest.
verses.textLa: et universis quorum accipitis primitias, offerte Domino, et date Aaron sacerdoti.

verses.textEn: Everything which you shall offer from the tithes, and which you shall separate as gifts to the Lord, shall be the finest and most select.
verses.textLa: Omnia quæ offeretis ex decimis, et in donaria Domini separabitis, optima et electa erunt.

verses.textEn: And you shall say to them: ‘If you offer the noble and the better of the tithes, it shall be accounted to you as if you had given from the first-fruits of the threshing floor and of the oil and wine presses.’
verses.textLa: Dicesque ad eos: Si præclara et meliora quæque obtuleritis ex decimis, reputabitur vobis quasi de area et torculari dederitis primitias:

verses.textEn: And you shall eat these in all your places, both you and your families, because it is your price for the ministry, by which you serve in the tabernacle of the testimony.
verses.textLa: et comedetis eas in omnibus locis vestris, tam vos quam familiæ vestræ: quia pretium est pro ministerio, quo servitis in tabernaculo testimonii.

verses.textEn: And you shall not sin in this way: by reserving the excellent and fat things for yourselves, lest you pollute the oblations of the sons of Israel, and lest you die.”
verses.textLa: Et non peccabitis super hoc, egregia vobis et pinguia reservantes ne polluatis oblationes filiorum Israel, et moriamini.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron, dicens:

verses.textEn: “This is the ritual that the Lord has appointed for a victim. Instruct the sons of Israel, so that they may bring to you a red cow of full maturity, in which there is no blemish, and which has not carried a yoke.
verses.textLa: Ista est religio victimæ, quam constituit Dominus. Præcipe filiis Israel, ut adducant ad te vaccam rufam ætatis integræ, in qua nulla sit macula, nec portaverit iugum:

verses.textEn: And you shall deliver it to Eleazar the priest, who, having led it out beyond the camp, shall immolate it in the sight of all.
verses.textLa: tradetisque eam Eleazaro sacerdoti, qui eductam extra castram, immolabit in conspectu omnium:

verses.textEn: And dipping his finger in its blood, he shall sprinkle it seven times, opposite the door of the tabernacle.
verses.textLa: et tingens digitum in sanguine eius, asperget contra fores tabernaculi septem vicibus,

verses.textEn: And he shall burn it, while all are watching, delivering into the flame, not only its skin and flesh, but also the blood and dung.
verses.textLa: comburetque eam cunctis videntibus, tam pelle et carnibus eius quam sanguine et fimo flammæ traditis.

verses.textEn: Likewise, cedar wood, and hyssop, and twice-dyed scarlet he shall cast into the flame, by which the cow is consumed.
verses.textLa: Lignum quoque cedrinum, et hyssopum, coccumque bis tinctum sacerdos mittet in flammam, quæ vaccam vorat.

verses.textEn: And then finally, having washed his garments and his body, he shall enter into the camp, and he shall be deeply stained until evening.
verses.textLa: Et tunc demum, lotis vestibus et corpore suo, ingredietur in castra, commaculatusque erit usque ad vesperum.
verses.notes: The word ‘commaculatusque’ is more intense than merely the word ‘macula’ (blemish).

verses.textEn: Then he also who had burned it shall wash his garments and his body, and he shall be unclean until evening.
verses.textLa: Sed et ille, qui combusserit eam, lavabit vestimenta sua, et corpus, et immundus erit usque ad vesperum.

verses.textEn: Then a clean man shall gather the ashes of the cow, and he shall pour them out beyond the camp, in a very pure place, so that they may be preserved for the multitude of the sons of Israel, and for the water of aspersion, because the cow was burned for sin.
verses.textLa: Colliget autem vir mundus cineres vaccæ, et effundet eos extra castra in loco purissimo, ut sint multitudini filiorum Israel in custodiam, et in aquam aspersionis: quia pro peccato vacca combusta est.

verses.textEn: And when he who had carried the ashes of the cow will have washed his garments, he shall be unclean until evening. The sons of Israel, and the newcomers who live among them, shall have this as a holy and perpetual right.
verses.textLa: Cumque laverit qui vaccæ portaverat cineres, vestimenta sua, immundus erit usque ad vesperum. Habebunt hoc filii Israel et advenæ, qui habitant inter eos, sanctum iure perpetuo.

verses.textEn: Whoever touches the corpse of a man, and is, because of this, unclean for seven days,
verses.textLa: Qui tetigerit cadaver hominis, et propter hoc septem diebus fuerit immundus:

verses.textEn: shall be sprinkled from this water on the third and seventh days, and so shall he be cleansed. But if he was not sprinkled on the third day, he is not able to be cleansed on the seventh.
verses.textLa: aspergetur ex hac aqua die tertio et septimo, et sic mundabitur. Si die tertio aspersus non fuerit, septimo non poterit emundari.

verses.textEn: Anyone who will have touched the dead body of a human life, and who has not been sprinkled with this mixture, pollutes the tabernacle of the Lord, and he shall perish out of Israel. For not having been sprinkled with the water of expiation, he shall be unclean, and his filth shall remain upon him.
verses.textLa: Omnis qui tetigerit humanæ animæ morticinum, et aspersus hac commistione non fuerit, polluet tabernaculum Domini, et peribit ex Israel: quia aqua expiationis non est aspersus, immundus erit, et manebit spurcitia eius super eum.

verses.textEn: This is the law of a man who dies in a tent. All who enter into his tent, and all the vessels which are there, shall be polluted for seven days.
verses.textLa: Ista est lex hominis qui moritur in tabernaculo: Omnes qui ingrediuntur tentorium illius, et universa vasa quæ ibi sunt, polluta erunt septem diebus.

verses.textEn: The vessel that has no cover or binding over it shall be unclean.
verses.textLa: Vas, quod non habuerit operculum, nec ligaturam desuper, immundum erit.

verses.textEn: If anyone in the field will have touched the corpse of a man, who was killed or who died on his own, or his bone, or his grave, he shall be unclean for seven days.
verses.textLa: Si quis in agro tetigerit cadaver occisi hominis, aut per se mortui, sive os illius, vel sepulchrum, immundus erit septem diebus.
verses.notes: Death is a result of original sin, which is why dead things render a person ritually impure, because the fall from grace was a serious sin resulting in death.

verses.textEn: And they shall take some of the ashes from the burning and the sin offering, and they shall pour living waters over them into a vessel.
verses.textLa: Tollentque de cineribus combustionis atque peccati, et mittent aquas vivas super eos in vas.

verses.textEn: And into it a man who is clean shall dip hyssop, and he shall sprinkle from it the entire tent, and all its articles, and the men who were polluted by means of contact.
verses.textLa: In quibus cum homo mundus tinxerit hyssopum, asperget ex eo omne tentorium, et cunctam supellectilem, et homines huiuscemodi contagione pollutos:

verses.textEn: And so, in this manner, what is clean shall purify what is unclean, on the third and seventh days. And having been expiated on the seventh day, he shall wash both himself and his garments, and he shall be unclean until evening.
verses.textLa: atque hoc modo mundus lustrabit immundum tertio et septimo die. Expiatusque die septimo, lavabit et se et vestimenta sua, et immundus erit usque ad vesperum.

verses.textEn: If anyone has not been expiated by this ritual, his soul shall perish from the midst of the Church. For he has polluted the Sanctuary of the Lord, and he has not been sprinkled with purifying waters.
verses.textLa: Si quis hoc ritu non fuerit expiatus, peribit anima illius de medio Ecclesiæ: quia Sanctuarium Domini polluit, et non est aqua lustrationis aspersus.
verses.notes: In this ritual is a great figure of the Sacrament of Baptism and its necessity for any soul to be saved. The use of the word Church favors the spiritual meaning of this verse; this is an example of the Christological translation of the Old Testament.

verses.textEn: This precept shall be an everlasting ordinance. Likewise, the one who has sprinkled the waters shall wash his garments. All who will have touched the waters of expiation shall be unclean until evening.
verses.textLa: Erit hoc præceptum legitimum sempiternum. Ipse quoque qui aspergit aquas, lavabit vestimenta sua: Omnis qui tetigerit aquas expiationis, immundus erit usque ad vesperum.

verses.textEn: Whatever has been touched by something unclean will itself be made unclean. And the soul who touches any of these things shall become unclean until evening.”
verses.textLa: Quidquid tetigerit immundus, immundum faciet: et anima, quæ horum quippiam tetigerit, immunda erit usque ad vesperum.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel, and the entire multitude, went into the desert of Sin, in the first month. And the people stayed at Kadesh. And Miriam died there, and she was buried in the same place.
verses.textLa: Veneruntque filii Israel, et omnis multitudo in desertum Sin, mense primo: et mansit populus in Cades. Mortuaque est ibi Maria, et sepulta in eodem loco.

verses.textEn: And when the people were in need of water, they came together against Moses and Aaron.
verses.textLa: Cumque indigeret aqua populus, convenerunt adversum Moysen et Aaron:

verses.textEn: And as it turned into sedition, they said: “If only we had perished among our brothers in the sight of the Lord.
verses.textLa: et versi in seditionem, dixerunt: Utinam periissemus inter fratres nostros coram Domino.

verses.textEn: Why have you led away the Church of the Lord, into the wilderness, so that both we and our cattle would die?
verses.textLa: Cur eduxistis Ecclesiam Domini in solitudinem, ut et nos et nostra iumenta moriamur?

verses.textEn: Why did you cause us to ascend from Egypt, and why have you led us into this most wretched place, which is not able to be sown, which does not produce figs, or vines, or pomegranates, and which, moreover, does not even have water to drink?”
verses.textLa: Quare nos fecistis ascendere de Ægypto, et adduxistis in locum istum pessimum, qui seri non potest, qui nec ficum gignit, nec vineas, nec malogranata, insuper et aquam non habet ad bibendum?

verses.textEn: And Moses and Aaron, dismissing the multitude, entered the tabernacle of the covenant, and they fell prone on the ground, and they cried out to the Lord, and they said: “O Lord God, listen to the outcry of this people, and open for them, from your storehouse, a fountain of living water, so that, being satisfied, their murmuring may cease.” And the glory of the Lord appeared over them.
verses.textLa: Ingressusque Moyses et Aaron, dimissa multitudine, tabernaculum fœderis, corruerunt proni in terram, clamaveruntque ad Dominum, atque dixerunt: Domine Deus audi clamorem huius populi, et aperi eis thesaurum tuum fontem aquæ vivæ, ut satiati, cesset murmuratio eorum. Et apparuit gloria Domini super eos.

verses.textEn: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.textLa: Locutusque est Dominus ad Moysen, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Take the rod, and gather the people, you and your brother Aaron, and speak to the rock before them, and it shall bestow waters. And when you have brought forth water from the rock, the entire multitude and their cattle shall drink.”
verses.textLa: Tolle virgam, et congrega populum, tu et Aaron frater tuus, et loquimini ad petram coram eis, et illa dabit aquas. Cumque eduxeris aquam de petra, bibet omnis multitudo et iumenta eius.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Moses took the rod, which was in the sight of the Lord, just as he had instructed him.
verses.textLa: Tulit igitur Moyses virgam, quæ erat in conspectu Domini, sicut præceperat ei,

verses.textEn: And having gathered the multitude before the rock, he said to them: “Listen, you who are rebellious and unbelieving. Would we be able to cast out water from this rock?”
verses.textLa: congregata multitudine ante petram, dixitque eis: Audite rebelles et increduli: Num de petra hac vobis aquam poterimus eiicere?

verses.textEn: And when Moses had lifted up his hand, striking the stone twice with the rod, very great waters went forth, so much so that the people and their cattle were able to drink.
verses.textLa: Cumque elevasset Moyses manum, percutiens virga bis silicem, egressæ sunt aquæ largissimæ, ita ut populus biberet et iumenta.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not believe me, so as to sanctify me before the sons of Israel, you shall not lead this people into the land, which I will give to them.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen et Aaron: Quia non credidistis mihi, ut sanctificaretis me coram filiis Israel, non introducetis hos populos in terram, quam dabo eis.

verses.textEn: This is the Water of Contradiction, where the sons of Israel were quarreling against the Lord, and he was sanctified in them.
verses.textLa: Hæc est Aqua Contradictionis, ubi iurgati sunt filii Israel contra Dominum, et sanctificatus est in eis.

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom. They said: “Your brother Israel says this: You know of all the hardships which have overtaken us,
verses.textLa: Misit interea nuncios Moyses de Cades ad regem Edom, qui dicerent: Hæc mandat frater tuus Israel: Nosti omnem laborem qui apprehendit nos,

verses.textEn: how our fathers descended into Egypt, and we lived there for a long time, and the Egyptians afflicted both us and our fathers,
verses.textLa: quo modo descenderint patres nostri in Ægyptum, et habitaverimus ibi multo tempore, afflixerintque nos Ægyptii, et patres nostros:

verses.textEn: and how we cried out to the Lord, and he heeded us and sent an Angel, who led us away from Egypt. Behold, we are situated in the city of Kadesh, which is at the extremity of your borders.
verses.textLa: et quo modo clamaverimus ad Dominum, et exaudierit nos, miseritque Angelum, qui eduxerit nos de Ægypto. Ecce, in urbe Cades, quæ est in extremis finibus tuis, positi,

verses.textEn: And we beg you to permit us to cross through your land. We will not go through the fields, nor through the vineyards; we will not drink the waters of your wells, but we will travel by the public ways, neither turning aside to the right, nor to the left, until we have passed your borders.”
verses.textLa: obsecramus ut nobis transire liceat per terram tuam. Non ibimus per agros, nec per vineas, non bibemus aquas de puteis tuis, sed gradiemur via publica, nec ad dexteram nec ad sinistram declinantes, donec transeamus terminos tuos.

verses.textEn: Edom responded to them: “You shall not cross through me, otherwise, I will meet you armed.”
verses.textLa: Cui respondit Edom: Non transibis per me, alioquin armatus occurram tibi.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel said: “We will travel by the well-trodden path. And if we or our cattle drink from your waters, we will give you what is just. There shall be no difficulty in the price, only let us cross through quickly.”
verses.textLa: Dixeruntque filii Israel: Per tritam gradiemur viam: et si biberimus aquas tuas nos et pecora nostra, dabimus quod iustum est: nulla erit in pretio difficultas, tantum velociter transeamus.

verses.textEn: But he answered, “You shall not cross.” And immediately he went out to meet them with a countless multitude and a strong hand;
verses.textLa: At ille respondit: Non transibis. Statimque egressus est obvius, cum infinita multitudo, et manu forti,

verses.textEn: neither was he willing to agree to their petition to concede passage through his borders. For this reason, Israel diverted away from him.
verses.textLa: nec voluit acquiescere deprecanti, ut concederet transitum per fines suos. Quam ob rem divertit ab eo Israel.

verses.textEn: And when they had moved the camp from Kadesh, they arrived at mount Hor, which is at the borders of the land of Edom,
verses.textLa: Cumque castra movissent de Cades, venerunt in montem Hor, qui est in finibus terræ Edom:

verses.textEn: where the Lord spoke to Moses:
verses.textLa: ubi locutus est Dominus ad Moysen:

verses.textEn: “Let Aaron,” he said, “go to his people. For he shall not enter into the land which I have given to the sons of Israel, because he did not believe my mouth at the Waters of Contradiction.
verses.textLa: Pergat, inquit, Aaron ad populos suos: non enim intrabit Terram, quam dedi filiis Israel, eo quod incredulus fuerit ori meo, ad Aquas Contradictionis.

verses.textEn: Take Aaron, and his son with him, and lead them on to mount Hor.
verses.textLa: Tolle Aaron et filium eius cum eo, et duces eos in montem Hor.

verses.textEn: And when you have stripped the father of his vestments, you shall put them on Eleazar, his son. Aaron shall be gathered and shall die there.”
verses.textLa: Cumque nudaveris patrem veste sua, indues ea Eleazarum filium eius: Aaron colligetur, et morietur ibi.

verses.textEn: Moses did just as the Lord had instructed. And they ascended mount Hor, in the sight of the entire multitude.
verses.textLa: Fecit Moyses ut præceperat Dominus: et ascenderunt in montem Hor coram omni multitudine.

verses.textEn: And when he had despoiled Aaron of his vestments, he clothed his son Eleazar with them.
verses.textLa: Cumque Aaron spoliasset vestibus suis, induit eis Eleazarum filium eius.

verses.textEn: And when Aaron had died at the top of the mountain, Moses came down with Eleazar.
verses.textLa: Illo mortuo in montis supercilio, descendit cum Eleazaro.

verses.textEn: And the entire multitude, seeing that Aaron lay dead, wept over him for thirty days, throughout all their families.
verses.textLa: Omnis autem multitudo videns occubuisse Aaron, flevit super eo triginta diebus per cunctas familias suas.

verses.textEn: And when king Arad the Canaanite, who was living toward the south, had heard this, namely, that Israel had arrived by the way of spies, he fought against them. And proving to be the victor, he led away prey from them.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset Chananæus rex Arad, qui habitabat ad meridiem, venisse scilicet Israel per exploratorum viam, pugnavit contra illum, et victor existens, duxit ex eo prædam.

verses.textEn: But Israel, obliging himself by a vow to the Lord, said: “If you deliver this people into my hand, I will wipe away their cities.”
verses.textLa: At Israel voto se Domino obligans, ait: Si tradideris populum istum in manu mea, delebo urbes eius.
verses.notes: Notice that the people of Israel are spoken of under the figure of one man named Israel.

verses.textEn: And the Lord heard the prayers of Israel, and he delivered the Canaanite, whom they put to death, overthrowing his cities. And they called the name of that place Hormah, that is, Anathema.
verses.textLa: Exaudivitque Dominus preces Israel, et tradidit Chananæum, quem ille interfecit subversis urbibus eius: et vocavit nomen loci illius Horma, id est, Anathema.

verses.textEn: Then they set out from mount Hor, by the way that leads to the Red Sea, to circle around the land of Edom. And the people began to tire of their journey and hardships.
verses.textLa: Profecti sunt autem et de monte Hor, per viam, quæ ducit ad Mare Rubrum, ut circumirent terram Edom. Et tædere cœpit populum itineris ac laboris:

verses.textEn: And speaking against God and Moses, they said: “Why did you lead us away from Egypt, so as to die in the wilderness? Bread is lacking; there are no waters. Our soul is now nauseous over this very light food.”
verses.textLa: locutusque contra Deum et Moysen, ait: Cur eduxisti nos de Ægypto, ut moreremur in solitudine? Deest panis, non sunt aquæ: anima nostra iam nauseat super cibo isto levissimo.

verses.textEn: For this reason, the Lord sent fiery serpents among the people, which wounded or killed many of them.
verses.textLa: Quamobrem misit Dominus in populum ignitos serpentes, ad quorum plagas et mortes plurimorum,

verses.textEn: And so they went to Moses, and they said: “We have sinned, because we have spoken against the Lord and against you. Pray, so that he may take away these serpents from us.” And Moses prayed for the people.
verses.textLa: venerunt ad Moysen, atque dixerunt: Peccavimus, quia locuti sumus contra Dominum et te: ora ut tollat a nobis serpentes. Oravitque Moyses pro populo,

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to him: “Make a bronze serpent, and place it as a sign. Whoever, having been struck, gazes upon it, shall live.”
verses.textLa: et locutus est Dominus ad eum: Fac serpentem æneum, et pone eum pro signo: qui percussus aspexerit eum, vivet.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Moses made a bronze serpent, and he placed it as a sign. When those who had been struck gazed upon it, they were healed.
verses.textLa: Fecit ergo Moyses serpentem æneum, et posuit eum pro signo: quem cum percussi aspicerent, sanabantur.

verses.textEn: And the sons of Israel, setting out, made camp at Oboth.
verses.textLa: Profectique filii Israel castrametati sunt in Oboth.

verses.textEn: Having departed from there, they pitched their tents at Iye-abarim, in the wilderness, which looks out toward Moab, opposite the eastern region.
verses.textLa: Unde egressi fixere tentoria in Ieabarim, in solitudine, quæ respicit Moab contra orientalem plagam.

verses.textEn: And moving from there, they arrived at the Torrent of Zared.
verses.textLa: Et inde moventes, venerunt ad Torrentem Zared.

verses.textEn: Having left that place behind, they then made camp opposite Arnon, which is in the desert, and which juts out at the borders of the Amorite. For certainly Arnon is at the limit of Moab, dividing the Moabites and the Amorites.
verses.textLa: Quem relinquentes castrametati sunt contra Arnon, quæ est in deserto, et prominet in finibus Amorrhæi. Si quidem Arnon terminus est Moab, dividens Moabitas et Amorrhæos.

verses.textEn: About this place, it is said in the book of the wars of the Lord: “As he did at the Red Sea, so will he do at the Torrents of Arnon.”
verses.textLa: Unde dicitur in libro bellorum Domini: Sicut fecit in Mari rubro, sic faciet in Torrentibus Arnon.
verses.notes: Here is an example of a written source, used in composing Scripture, where the source itself, as a whole, is fallible and non-inspired, but a quote from it is part of inspired Scripture. Pre-existing written (and oral) source material was used, to some extent, when Scripture was written.

verses.textEn: The stones of the torrents were bent, so that they might rest in Ar and lie back within the borders of the Moabites.
verses.textLa: Scopuli torrentium inclinati sunt, ut requiescerent in Ar, et recumberent in finibus Moabitarum.
verses.notes: It is as if the stones themselves are rejecting the Amorites.

verses.textEn: Beyond that place appeared a well, about which the Lord said to Moses: “Gather the people together, and I will give them water.”
verses.textLa: Ex eo loco apparuit puteus, super quo locutus est Dominus ad Moysen: Congrega populum, et dabo ei aquam.

verses.textEn: Then Israel sang this verse: “Let the well rise up.” They sang:
verses.textLa: Tunc cecinit Israel carmen istud: Ascendat puteus. Concinebant:

verses.textEn: “The well, the leaders dug it, and the commanders of the multitude prepared it, at the direction of the lawgiver, and with their staffs.”
verses.textLa: Puteus, quem foderunt principes, et paraverunt duces multitudinis in datore legis, et in baculis suis.

verses.textEn: They went from the wilderness to Mattanah, from Mattanah to Nahaliel, from Nahaliel to Bamoth,
verses.textLa: De solitudine, Matthana. De Matthana in Nahaliel: de Nahaliel, in Bamoth.

verses.textEn: from Bamoth, a valley in the region of Moab, to the top of Pisgah, which looks out opposite the desert.
verses.textLa: De Bamoth, vallis est in regione Moab, in vertice Phasga, quod respicit contra desertum.

verses.textEn: Then Israel sent messengers to Sihon, the king of the Amorites, saying:
verses.textLa: Misit autem Israel nuncios ad Sehon regem Amorrhæorum, dicens:

verses.textEn: “I beg you to permit me to cross through your land. We will not turn aside into the fields or the vineyards. We will not drink waters from the wells. We will travel by the royal way, until we have passed your borders.”
verses.textLa: Obsecro ut transire mihi liceat per terram tuam: non declinabimus in agros et vineas, non bibemus aquas ex puteis, via regia gradiemur, donec transeamus terminos tuos.

verses.textEn: And he was not willing to allow Israel to cross through his borders. But instead, gathering an army, he went out to meet them in the desert, and he arrived at Jahaz and fought against them.
verses.textLa: Qui concedere noluit ut transiret Israel per fines suos: quin potius exercitu congregato, egressus est obviam in desertum, et venit in Iasa, pugnavitque contra eum.

verses.textEn: And he was struck down by them with the edge of the sword, and they possessed his land from Arnon, even to Jabbok and the sons of Ammon. For the borders of the Ammonites were held by a strong fortress.
verses.textLa: A quo percussus est in ore gladii, et possessa est terra eius ab Arnon usque Ieboc, et filios Ammon: quia forti præsidio tenebantur termini Ammonitarum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, Israel took all his cities and lived in the cities of the Amorite, namely, in Heshbon and its villages.
verses.textLa: Tulit ergo Israel omnes civitates eius, et habitavit in urbibus Amorrhæi, in Hesebon scilicet, et viculis eius.

verses.textEn: Heshbon was the city of Sihon, the king of the Amorites, who fought against the king of Moab. And he took all the land, which had been under his sovereignty, as far as Arnon.
verses.textLa: Urbs Hesebon fuit Sehon regis Amorrhæi, qui pugnavit contra regem Moab: et tulit omnem terram, quæ ditionis illius fuerat, usque Arnon.

verses.textEn: About this, it is said in the proverb: “Enter into Heshbon. Let the city of Sihon be established and built.
verses.textLa: Idcirco dicitur in Proverbio: Venite in Hesebon, ædificetur, et construatur civitas Sehon:

verses.textEn: A fire has gone forth from Heshbon, a flame from the town of Sihon, and it has devoured Ar of the Moabites, and the inhabitants of the heights of Arnon.
verses.textLa: Ignis egressus est de Hesebon, flamma de oppido Sehon, et devoravit Ar Moabitarum, et habitatores excelsorum Arnon.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, Moab! You are perishing, O people of Chemosh. He gave flight to his sons, and he gave the daughters into captivity, to the king of the Amorites, Sihon.
verses.textLa: Væ tibi Moab, peristi popule Chamos. Dedit filios eius in fugam, et filias in captivitatem regi Amorrhæorum Sehon.

verses.textEn: Their yoke has been scattered from Heshbon even to Dibon. They have passed through, wearily, into Nophah, and as far as Medeba.”
verses.textLa: Iugum ipsorum disperiit ad Hesebon usque Dibon, lassi pervenerunt in Nophe, et usque Medaba.

verses.textEn: And so Israel lived in the land of the Amorite.
verses.textLa: Habitavit itaque Israel in Terra Amorrhæi.

verses.textEn: And Moses sent some to explore Jazer. These captured its villages and possessed its inhabitants.
verses.textLa: Misitque Moyses qui explorarent Iazer: cuius ceperunt viculos, et possederunt habitatores.

verses.textEn: And they turned themselves and ascended, along the way of Bashan. And Og, the king of Bashan, met them with all his people, to fight at Edrei.
verses.textLa: Verteruntque se, et ascenderunt per viam Basan, et occurrit eis Og rex Basan cum omni populo suo, pugnaturus in Edrai.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to Moses: “Do not be afraid of him. For I have delivered him, and all his people, as well as his land, into your hand. And you shall do to him just as you did to Sihon, the king of the Amorites, the inhabitant of Heshbon.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Ne timeas eum, quia in manu tua tradidi illum, et omnem populum, ac terram eius: faciesque illi sicut fecisti Sehon regi Amorrhæorum habitatori Hesebon.

verses.textEn: Therefore, they struck him down also, with his sons, and all his people, even to utter destruction, and they possessed his land.
verses.textLa: Percusserunt igitur et hunc cum filiis suis, universumque populum eius usque ad internecionem, et possederunt terram illius.

verses.textEn: And they set out and made camp in the plains of Moab, across the Jordan, where Jericho is situated.
verses.textLa: Profectique castrametati sunt in campestribus Moab, ubi trans Iordanem Iericho sita est.

verses.textEn: Then Balak, the son of Zippor, seeing all that Israel had done to the Amorite,
verses.textLa: Videns autem Balac filius Sephor omnia quæ fecerat Israel Amorrhæo,

verses.textEn: and that the Moabites had great fear of him, and that they were not able to bear his assault,
verses.textLa: et quod pertimuissent eum Moabitæ, et impetum eius ferre non possent,

verses.textEn: said to those greater by birth of Midian: “So will this people wipe away all those who are dwelling within our borders, in the same way that the ox is accustomed to tear out grass, all the way to the roots.” At that time, he was king of Moab.
verses.textLa: dixit ad maiores natu Madian: Ita delebit hic populus omnes, qui in nostris finibus commorantur, quo modo solet bos herbas usque ad radices carpere. Ipse erat eo tempore rex in Moab.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he sent messengers to Balaam, the son of Beor, a seer who lived above the river of the land of the sons of Ammon, to call him, and to say: “Behold, a people has gone forth from Egypt, which has covered the face of the earth. They are encamped opposite me.
verses.textLa: Misit ergo nuncios ad Balaam filium Beor ariolum, qui habitabat super flumen terræ filiorum Ammon, ut vocarent eum, et dicerent: Ecce egressus est populus ex Ægypto, qui operuit superficiem terræ, sedens contra me.

verses.textEn: Therefore, come and curse this people, for they are stronger than I am. If only, in some way, I might be able to strike them and to drive them from my land. For I know that he whom you bless shall be blessed, and he whom you curse shall be cursed.”
verses.textLa: Veni igitur, et maledic populo huic, quia fortior me est: Si quo modo possim percutere et eiicere eum de terra mea. Novi enim quod benedictus sit cui benedixeris, et maledictus in quem maledicta congesseris.

verses.textEn: And the elders of Moab, and those greater by birth of Midian, continued on, holding the price of divination in their hands. And when they had come to Balaam, and had explained to him all the words of Balak,
verses.textLa: Perrexeruntque seniores Moab, et maiores natu Madian, habentes divinationis pretium in manibus. Cumque venissent ad Balaam, et narrassent ei omnia verba Balac:

verses.textEn: he responded, “Remain for this night, and I will answer with whatever the Lord will say to me.” And while they stayed with Balaam, God came and said to him,
verses.textLa: ille respondit: Manete hic nocte, et respondebo quidquid mihi dixerit Dominus. Manentibus illis apud Balaam, venit Deus, et ait ad eum:

verses.textEn: “What do these men want with you?”
verses.textLa: Quid sibi volunt homines isti apud te?

verses.textEn: He responded, “Balak, the son of Zippor, the king of the Moabites has sent to me,
verses.textLa: Respondit: Balac filius Sephor rex Moabitarum misit ad me,

verses.textEn: saying: ‘Behold, a people, which has gone forth from Egypt, has covered the face of the earth. Come and curse them, so that, in some way, I may be able to fight them and drive them away.’ ”
verses.textLa: dicens: Ecce populus qui egressus est de Ægypto, operuit superficiem terræ: veni, et maledic ei, si quo modo possim pugnans abigere eum.

verses.textEn: And God said to Balaam, “Do not go with them, and do not curse the people, for they are blessed.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Deus ad Balaam: Noli ire cum eis, neque maledicas populo: quia benedictus est.

verses.textEn: And he, rising up in the morning, said to the leaders, “Go into your own land, for the Lord has prohibited me from going with you.”
verses.textLa: Qui mane consurgens dixit ad principes: Ite in terram vestram, quia prohibuit me Dominus venire vobiscum.

verses.textEn: Returning, the leaders said to Balak, “Balaam was not willing to come with us.”
verses.textLa: Reversi principes dixerunt ad Balac: Noluit Balaam venire nobiscum.

verses.textEn: Again, he sent many more persons, and these were more noble than those he had sent before.
verses.textLa: Rursum ille multo plures et nobiliores quam ante miserat, misit.

verses.textEn: And when these had come to Balaam, they said: “So says Balak, the son of Zippor. Do not hesitate to come to me.
verses.textLa: Qui cum venissent ad Balaam, dixerunt: Sic dicit Balac filius Sephor: Ne cuncteris venire ad me:

verses.textEn: For I am ready to honor you, and whatever you would want, I shall give to you. Come and curse this people.”
verses.textLa: paratus sum honorare te, et quidquid volueris dabo tibi: veni, et maledic populo isti.

verses.textEn: Balaam responded: “Even if Balak were to give to me his own house, filled with silver and gold, I still would not be able to change the word of the Lord my God, neither to say more, nor to say less.
verses.textLa: Respondit Balaam: Si dederit mihi Balac plenam domum suam argenti et auri, non potero immutare verbum Domini Dei mei, ut vel plus, vel minus loquar.

verses.textEn: I beg you to remain for this night also, so that I may know what the Lord will answer me again.”
verses.textLa: Obsecro ut hic maneatis etiam hac nocte, et scire queam quid mihi rursum respondeat Dominus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, God came to Balaam in the night, and said to him: “If these men have arrived to call you, then rise up and go with them; yet only in so far as you shall do what I will command you.”
verses.textLa: Venit ergo Deus ad Balaam nocte, et ait ei: Si vocare te venerunt homines isti, surge, et vade cum eis: ita dumtaxat, ut quod tibi præcepero, facias.

verses.textEn: Balaam rose up in the morning, and saddling his donkey, he set out with them.
verses.textLa: Surrexit Balaam mane, et strata asina sua profectus est cum eis.

verses.textEn: And God was angry. And an Angel of the Lord stood in the way opposite Balaam, who was sitting on the donkey, and he had two servants with him.
verses.textLa: Et iratus est Deus. Stetitque Angelus Domini in via contra Balaam, qui insidebat asinæ, et duos pueros habebat secum.
verses.notes: God was angry, perhaps because Balaam had not yet resolved to resist the will of Balak and to do only God’s will. He agreed to go on the journey, but he did not yet have the right attitude for that journey.

verses.textEn: The donkey, discerning that the Angel was standing in the way with a drawn sword, turned herself from the road and went through a field. And when Balaam beat her and intended to return her to the path,
verses.textLa: Cernens asina Angelum stantem in via, evaginato gladio, avertit se de itinere, et ibat per agrum. Quam cum verberaret Balaam, et vellet ad semitam reducere,

verses.textEn: the Angel stood in a narrow place between the two walls, with which the vineyards were enclosed.
verses.textLa: stetit Angelus in angustiis duarum maceriarum, quibus vineæ cingebantur.

verses.textEn: And the donkey, seeing this, drew herself close to the wall and scraped the foot of the rider. So he beat her again.
verses.textLa: Quem videns asina, iunxit se parieti, et attrivit sedentis pedem. At ille iterum verberabat eam:

verses.textEn: And, nevertheless, the Angel passing on to a narrow place, where one would not be able to deviate either to the right or to the left, stood to meet him.
verses.textLa: et nihilominus Angelus ad locum angustum transiens, ubi nec ad dexteram, nec ad sinistram poterat deviare, obvius stetit.

verses.textEn: And when the donkey had seen the Angel standing there, she fell under the feet of the rider, who, being angry, struck her sides more vehemently with a club.
verses.textLa: Cumque vidisset asina stantem Angelum, concidit sub pedibus sedentis: qui iratus, vehementius cædebat fuste latera eius.

verses.textEn: And the Lord opened the mouth of the donkey, and she said: “What have I done to you? Why do strike you me, behold now, for the third time?”
verses.textLa: Aperuitque Dominus os asinæ, et locuta est: Quid feci tibi? cur percutis me, ecce iam tertio?

verses.textEn: Balaam responded, “Because you have deserved it, and you have mistreated me. If only I had a sword, so that I might pierce you.”
verses.textLa: Respondit Balaam: Quia commeruisti, et illusisti mihi: utinam haberem gladium, ut te percuterem.

verses.textEn: The donkey said: “Am not I your animal, on which you have always been accustomed to sit, even until this present day? Tell me, when did I ever do the same thing to you.” But he said, “Never.”
verses.textLa: Dixit asina: Nonne animal tuum sum, cui semper sedere consuevisti usque in præsentem diem? dic quid simile umquam fecerim tibi. At ille ait: Numquam.

verses.textEn: Immediately, the Lord opened the eyes of Balaam, and he saw the Angel standing in the way with a drawn sword, and he reverenced him prone on the ground.
verses.textLa: Protinus aperuit Dominus oculos Balaam, et vidit Angelum stantem in via evaginato gladio, adoravitque eum pronus in terram.

verses.textEn: And the Angel said to him: “Why did you beat your donkey three times? I have come to be an adversary to you, because your way is perverse and contrary to me.
verses.textLa: Cui Angelus: Cur, inquit, tertio verberas asinam tuam? Ego veni ut adversarer tibi, quia perversa est via tua, mihique contraria:

verses.textEn: And unless the donkey had turned aside from the way, allowing a place for my opposition, I would have killed you, and she would have lived.”
verses.textLa: et nisi asina declinasset de via, dans locum resistenti, te occidissem, et illa viveret.

verses.textEn: Balaam said: “I have sinned, not knowing that you stood against me. And now, if it displeases you for me to continue on, I will return.”
verses.textLa: Dixit Balaam: Peccavi, nesciens quod tu stares contra me: et nunc si displicet tibi ut vadam, revertar.

verses.textEn: The Angel said, “Go with them, but be careful not to speak anything other than what I shall instruct you.” And so, he went with the leaders.
verses.textLa: Ait Angelus: Vade cum istis, et cave ne aliud quam præcepero tibi loquaris. Ivit igitur cum principibus.

verses.textEn: And when Balak had heard it, he went out to meet him in a town of the Moabites, which is situated at the furthest borders of Arnon.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset Balac, egressus est in occursum eius in oppido Moabitarum, quod situm est in extremis finibus Arnon.

verses.textEn: And he said to Balaam: “I sent messengers to call you. Why did you not come to me immediately? Was it because I am not able to pay the cost for your arrival?”
verses.textLa: Dixitque ad Balaam: Misi nuncios ut vocarent te, cur non statim venisti ad me? an quia mercedem adventui tuo reddere nequeo?

verses.textEn: He answered him: “Behold, here I am. Am I able to speak anything other than what God will put into my mouth?”
verses.textLa: Cui ille respondit: Ecce adsum: numquid loqui potero aliud, nisi quod Deus posuerit in ore meo?

verses.textEn: Therefore, they continued on together, and they arrived at a city, which was at the furthest borders of his kingdom.
verses.textLa: Perrexerunt ergo simul, et venerunt in urbem, quæ in extremis regni eius finibus erat.

verses.textEn: And after Balak had killed oxen and sheep, he sent the gifts to Balaam, and to the leaders who were with him.
verses.textLa: Cumque occidisset Balac boves et oves, misit ad Balaam, et principes qui cum eo erant, munera.

verses.textEn: Then, when morning arrived, he led him to the heights of Baal, and he gazed upon the most distant portions of the population.
verses.textLa: Mane autem facto duxit eum ad excelsa Baal, et intuitus est extremam partem populi.

verses.textEn: And Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars here for me, and prepare as many calves, and the same number of rams.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Balaam ad Balac: Ædifica mihi hic septem aras, et para totidem vitulos, eiusdemque numeri arietes.

verses.textEn: And when he had acted according to the words of Balaam, they placed a calf and a ram together on each altar.
verses.textLa: Cumque fecisset iuxta sermonem Balaam, imposuerunt simul vitulum et arietem super aram.

verses.textEn: And Balaam said to Balak: “Stand for a little while next to your holocaust, until I go, to see if perhaps the Lord will meet with me. And whatever he will command, I shall speak to you.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Balaam ad Balac: Sta paulisper iuxta holocaustum tuum, donec vadam, si forte occurrat mihi Dominus, et quodcumque imperaverit, loquar tibi.

verses.textEn: And after he had quickly departed, God met with him. And Balaam, speaking to him, said: “I have set up seven altars, and I have placed a calf and a ram on each.”
verses.textLa: Cumque abiisset velociter, occurrit illi Deus. Locutusque ad eum Balaam: Septem, inquit, aras erexi, et imposui vitulum et arietem desuper.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord placed the word in his mouth, and he said: “Return to Balak, and you shall say this.”
verses.textLa: Dominus autem posuit verbum in ore eius, et ait: Revertere ad Balac, et hæc loqueris.

verses.textEn: Returning, he found Balak standing next to his holocaust, with all the leaders of the Moabites.
verses.textLa: Reversus invenit stantem Balac iuxta holocaustum suum, et omnes principes Moabitarum:

verses.textEn: And taking up his parable, he said: “Balak, king of the Moabites, has led me from Aram, from the mountains of the east. ‘Come forth,’ he said, ‘and curse Jacob. Hurry and condemn Israel.’
verses.textLa: assumptaque parabola sua, dixit: De Aram adduxit me Balac rex Moabitarum, de montibus Orientis: Veni, inquit, et maledic Iacob: propera, et detestare Israel.

verses.textEn: How shall I curse him, whom God has not cursed? For what reason would I condemn him, whom the Lord does not condemn?
verses.textLa: Quo modo maledicam, cui non maledixit Deus? Qua ratione detester, quem Dominus non detestatur?

verses.textEn: I will look upon him from the tops of the stones, and I will consider him from the hills. This people shall dwell alone, and they shall not be counted among the nations.
verses.textLa: De summis silicibus videbo eum, et de collibus considerabo illum. Populus solus habitabit, et inter gentes non reputabitur.

verses.textEn: Who can number the dust that is Jacob, and who can know the number of the stock of Israel? May my soul die a just death, and may my end be like theirs.”
verses.textLa: Quis dinumerare possit pulverem Iacob, et nosse numerum stirpis Israel? Moriatur anima mea morte iustorum, et fiant novissima mea horum similia.

verses.textEn: And Balak said to Balaam: “What is this that you are doing? I called for you, in order to curse my enemies, and to the contrary, you bless them.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Balac ad Balaam: Quid est hoc quod agis? Ut malediceres inimicis meis vocavi te: et tu econtrario benedicis eis.

verses.textEn: He answered him, “How can I say anything other than what the Lord orders?”
verses.textLa: Cui ille respondit: Num aliud possum loqui, nisi quod iusserit Dominus?

verses.textEn: Therefore, Balak said: “Come with me to another place, from where you may see a portion of Israel, though you cannot see them all. Curse them from there.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo Balac: Veni mecum in alterum locum unde partem Israel videas, et totum videre non possis, inde maledicito ei.

verses.textEn: And when he had led him to a lofty place, on the top of mount Pisgah, Balaam built seven altars, and placing upon each a calf and a ram,
verses.textLa: Cumque duxisset eum in locum sublimem, super verticem montis Phasga, ædificavit Balaam septem aras, et impositis supra vitulo atque ariete,

verses.textEn: he said to Balak, “Stand here next to your holocaust, while I continue on to meet him.”
verses.textLa: dixit ad Balac: Sta hic iuxta holocaustum tuum, donec ego obvius pergam.

verses.textEn: And when the Lord had met him, and had put the word in his mouth, he said, “Return to Balak, and you shall say this to him.”
verses.textLa: Cui cum Dominus occurrisset, posuissetque verbum in ore eius, ait: Revertere ad Balac, et hæc loqueris ei.

verses.textEn: Returning, he found him standing next to his holocaust, and the leaders of the Moabites were with him. And Balak said to him, “What has the Lord spoken?”
verses.textLa: Reversus invenit eum stantem iuxta holocaustum suum, et principes Moabitarum cum eo. Ad quem Balac: Quid, inquit, locutus est Dominus?

verses.textEn: But, taking up his parable, he said: “Stand, Balak, and pay attention. Listen, you son of Zippor.
verses.textLa: At ille assumpta parabola sua, ait: Sta Balac, et ausculta, audi fili Sephor:

verses.textEn: God is not like a man, so that he would lie, nor is he like a son of man, so that he would be changed. Therefore, having spoken, will he not act? Has he ever spoken, and not fulfilled?
verses.textLa: Non est Deus quasi homo, ut mentiatur: nec ut filius hominis, ut mutetur. Dixit ergo, et non faciet? Locutus est, et non implebit?

verses.textEn: I was led here to bless, and I have no strength to hinder the blessing.
verses.textLa: Ad benedicendum adductus sum, benedictionem prohibere non valeo.

verses.textEn: There is no idol in Jacob; neither is there a false image to be seen in Israel. The Lord his God is with him, and the resound of royal victory is in him.
verses.textLa: Non est idolum in Iacob, nec videtur simulacrum in Israel. Dominus Deus eius cum eo est, et clangor victoriæ regis in illo.

verses.textEn: God has led him away from Egypt; his strength is like that of the rhinoceros.
verses.textLa: Deus eduxit illum de Ægypto, cuius fortitudo similis est rhinocerotis.

verses.textEn: There is no soothsaying in Jacob, nor any divination in Israel. In their times, it shall be told to Jacob and to Israel what God has wrought.
verses.textLa: Non est augurium in Iacob, nec divinatio in Israel. Temporibus suis dicetur Iacob et Israeli quid operatus sit Deus.

verses.textEn: Behold, the people will rise up like a lioness, and lie down like a lion. But they will not lie down until they devour the prey and drink the blood of the slain.”
verses.textLa: Ecce populus ut leæna consurget, et quasi leo erigetur: non accubabit donec devoret prædam, et occisorum sanguinem bibat.

verses.textEn: And Balak said to Balaam, “Neither curse him, nor bless him.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Balac ad Balaam: Nec maledicas ei, nec benedicas.

verses.textEn: And he said, “Have I not told you that whatever God would command of me, I would do?”
verses.textLa: Et ille ait: Nonne dixi tibi quod quidquid mihi Deus imperaret, hoc facerem?

verses.textEn: And Balak said to him: “Come and I will lead you to another place. If perhaps it may please God, then you may curse them from there.”
verses.textLa: Et ait Balac ad eum: Veni, et ducam te ad alium locum: si forte placeat Deo ut inde maledicas eis.

verses.textEn: And when he had led him on to the top of mount Peor, which looks out toward the wilderness,
verses.textLa: Cumque duxisset eum super verticem montis Phogor, qui respicit solitudinem,

verses.textEn: Balaam said to him, “Build seven altars here for me, and prepare as many calves, and the same number of rams.”
verses.textLa: dixit ei Balaam: Ædifica mihi hic septem aras, et para totidem vitulos, eiusdemque numeri arietes.

verses.textEn: Balak did as Balaam had said, and he placed on each altar a calf and a ram.
verses.textLa: Fecit Balac ut Balaam dixerat: imposuitque vitulos et arietes per singulas aras.

verses.textEn: And when Balaam had seen that it was pleasing to the Lord that he should bless Israel, he by no means went out as he had gone before, to seek divination. But directing his face opposite the desert,
verses.textLa: Cumque vidisset Balaam quod placeret Domino ut benediceret Israeli, nequaquam abiit ut ante perrexerat, ut augurium quæreret: sed dirigens contra desertum vultum suum,

verses.textEn: and lifting up his eyes, he saw Israel dwelling in tents by their tribes. And with the Spirit of God rushing into him,
verses.textLa: et elevans oculos, vidit Israel in tentoriis commorantem per tribus suas: et irruente in se Spiritu Dei,

verses.textEn: taking up his parable, he said: “Balaam, the son of Beor, the man whose eye has been obstructed,
verses.textLa: assumpta parabola, ait: Dixit Balaam filius Beor: dixit homo, cuius obturatus est oculus:

verses.textEn: the hearer of the sermon of God, he who has gazed upon a vision of the Almighty, he who falls down and so his eyes are opened, has declared:
verses.textLa: dixit auditor sermonum Dei, qui visionem Omnipotentis intuitus est, qui cadit, et sic aperiuntur oculi eius:

verses.textEn: ‘How beautiful are your tabernacles, O Jacob, and your tents, O Israel!
verses.textLa: Quam pulchra tabernacula tua Iacob, et tentoria tua Israel!

verses.textEn: They are like forested valleys, like gardens irrigated next to rivers, like tabernacles which the Lord has fixed, like cedars close to waters.
verses.textLa: ut valles nemorosæ, ut horti iuxta fluvios irrigui, ut tabernacula quæ fixit Dominus, quasi cedri prope aquas.

verses.textEn: Water shall flow from his jar, and his offspring shall be amid many waters, because Agag, his king, shall be taken, and his kingdom shall be removed.
verses.textLa: Fluet aqua de situla eius, et semen illius erit in aquas multas. Tolletur propter Agag, rex eius, et auferetur regnum illius.

verses.textEn: Away from Egypt, God has led him, whose strength is like the rhinoceros. They shall devour the nations that are his enemies, and break their bones, and pierce them with arrows.
verses.textLa: Deus eduxit illum de Ægypto, cuius fortitudo similis est rhinocerotis. Devorabunt gentes hostes illius, ossaque eorum confringent, et perforabunt sagittis.

verses.textEn: Lying down, he has slept like a lion, and like a lioness, whom no one would dare to awaken. He who blesses you, shall himself also be blessed. He who curses you, shall be considered cursed.”
verses.textLa: Accubans dormivit ut leo, et quasi leæna, quam suscitare nullus audebit. Qui benedixerit tibi, erit et ipse benedictus: qui maledixerit, in maledictione reputabitur.
